Questions? See [[Special:Diff/869750233|the RfC]] or [[User talk:TheSandDoctor|msg TSD!]] ([[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/TheSandBot|BRFA in progress]]; please mention that this is task #1!))
revision.text:
{{cherry picked|date=January 2013}} {{ElectionsCA}} '''Proposition 29''', the California Cancer Research Act, is a [[California ballot measure]] that was defeated by California voters at the [[California state elections, June 2012|statewide election on June 5, 2012]].
The measure would have placed a $1 [[excise]] on tobacco products into a protected fund to finance medical research on smoking-related illnesses, strengthen California’s smoking prevention and cessation programs, and enforce the state’s existing tobacco laws.
The independent [[California Legislative Analyst's Office]] projected that the measure would have generated approximately $855 million in first year, declining slightly but predictably (about 3% annually due to decrease in the number of smokers) every year thereafter. <ref>[http://www.lao.ca.gov/ballot/2009/090811.pdf California Legislative Analyst’s Office, January 15, 2010]</ref>
The measure would have created a nine-member committee charged with administering direct revenues. This oversight committee was to be composed of cancer-research medical professionals, [[University of California]] Chancellors, and representatives of national disease advocacy groups. The measure restricted administration costs to no more than 2% of its direct tax revenues.<ref>[http://ag.ca.gov/cms_attachments/initiatives/pdfs/i895_initiative_09-0097.pdf Full text of the California Cancer Research Act]</ref>
The California Cancer Research Act was widely supported by cancer advocates, including [[cancer survivor]] [[Lance Armstrong]] and the [[American Cancer Society]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.californiansforacure.org/about/Steering_Committee# |title=Steering Committee of the Campaign to Pass the California Cancer Research Act |access-date=2011-04-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911144731/http://www.californiansforacure.org/about/Steering_Committee# |archive-date=2011-09-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Detail==
===How CCRA revenue would have been spent=== According to the independent [[California Legislative Analyst's Office]], revenue raised by the measure would have been spent as follows:<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/ballot-measures/qualified-ballot-measures.htm# |title=California Secretary of State, Qualified California Ballot Measures |access-date=2011-04-12 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6Pc81JxoZ?url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/ballot-measures/qualified-ballot-measures.htm# |archive-date=2014-05-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> * Approximately $75 million annually: Maintaining existing tobacco tax revenue streams to ensure that the [[California Proposition 99 (1988)]], [[California Proposition 10 (1998)]], General Fund and Breast Cancer programs funded by existing tobacco taxes are not negatively impacted by the [[excise]] tax increase; * 60% (approximately $468 million annually): Research of cancer and tobacco-related disease "for the purpose of grants and loans to support research into the prevention, early detection, treatments, complementary treatments and potential cures of lung cancer and other types of cancer, cardiovascular disease, emphysema and other tobacco related diseases, including but not limited to coronary heart disease, and chronic obstructive lung disease"; * 15% (approximately $117 million annually): Facilities and capital equipment for research "for the purposes of grants and loans to provide facilities, including but not limited to those building, building leases and capital equipment as may be found necessary and appropriate by the Committee, to further [[biomedical]], [[epidemiological]], behavioral, health services, and other research whose primary focus is to identify and refine promising prevention, early detection, treatments, complementary treatments, rehabilitation and potential cures of [[lung cancer]] and other types of cancer, [[cardiovascular disease]], [[emphysema]] and other tobacco related diseases"; * 20% (approximately $156 million annually): Tobacco prevention and cessation to the state’s existing tobacco control program. These funds would be divided between the [[California Department of Public Health]] (80%) and the [[California Department of Education]] (20%) for their existing programs to prevent and reduce the use of tobacco. * 3% (approximately $23 million annually): Tobacco law enforcement "to support law enforcement efforts to reduce [[cigarette smuggling]], tobacco tax evasion, and counterfeit tobacco products, to reduce illegal sales of tobacco products to minors, and to enforce legal settlement provisions and conduct law enforcement training and technical assistance activities for tobacco related statues". * No more than 2% (approximately $16 million annually): Administration.
===Oversight=== The measure would have created a 9-member governing committee charged with administering the fund. The California Cancer Research Act Oversight Committee was to be composed of:<ref>[http://www.californiansforacure.com/facts/initiative Full Text of the California Cancer Research Act]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * 3 [[University of California]] chancellors; * 3 "selected from among Cancer Center Directors of [[National Cancer Institute]] designated cancer centers located within the State of California" (appointed by the [[California Governor]]) * 1 "affiliated with a California Academic Medical Center who is a practicing [[physician]] with expertise in the prevention, treatment or research of [[cardiovascular disease]]" (appointed by the [[California Governor]]) * 2 "selected from among California representatives of California or national disease advocacy groups whose focus is tobacco-related illness, at least one of whom shall be a person who has been treated for a tobacco related illness." (appointed by Director of [[California Department of Public Health]]) * A Committee to establish a peer review process for selection of grants modeled on the process used by the [[National Institutes of Health]].
==Ballot qualification== The [[California Secretary of State]] confirmed that The California Cancer Research Act had qualified for California’s next statewide ballot on August 24, 2010, after its supporting coalition submitted 633,453 voter signatures for verification in June 2010. To qualify, the measure required 433,971 signatures, or more.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/ballot-measures/qualified-ballot-measures.htm# |title=California Secretary of State, Qualified California Ballot Measures |access-date=2011-04-12 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6Pc81JxoZ?url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/ballot-measures/qualified-ballot-measures.htm# |archive-date=2014-05-16 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Election results== [[File:CA2012Prop29.svg|right|200px|thumb|Results by county.]] {{Referendum | name = Proposition 29 | title = Tax on Cigarettes for Cancer Research | no = 2,592,791 | nopct = 50.2 | yes = 2,568,715 | yespct = 49.8 | valid = | validpct = | invalid = | invalidpct = | total = 5,161,506 | turnoutpct = | electorate = 23,713,027 | 100% }}<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/sov/2012-primary/pdf/13-sov-summary.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-07-14 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018061728/http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/sov/2012-primary/pdf/13-sov-summary.pdf# |archive-date=2012-10-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Tobacco in the United States]] * [[California Proposition 10 (1998)]] * [[California Proposition 56 (2016)]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://ag.ca.gov/cms_attachments/initiatives/pdfs/i895_initiative_09-0097.pdf Letter to Attorney General Requesting Ballot Title] * [http://www.californiansforacure.com/facts/initiative Full Text of the California Cancer Research Act]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * [http://www.stopoutofcontrolspending.com/ Opposition Website] * [http://vote.sos.ca.gov/returns/maps/ballot-measures/prop/29/ Clickable Map from the Secretary of State to county-by-county returns and results for Proposition 29]
{{CA2012elections}}
[[Category:California ballot propositions, 2012]] [[Category:Taxation in California]] [[Category:Tobacco control]] [[Category:Smoking in the United States]] [[Category:Health in California]] [[Category:United States state health legislation]] [[Category:Initiatives in the United States]]

page.title: 2016 Angola and DR Congo yellow fever outbreak

revision.text:
{|class="wikitable" align="right" width="230px" | '''2016 Angola and DR Congo yellow fever outbreak''' |- | [[File:2016 Angola and DR Congo yellow fever outbreak.png|220px|border]] |- | As of 28 October 2016<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 28 October 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/28-october-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=8 December 2016}}</ref> |- |style="background: #ff7272;"| '''[[Angola]]''' * 884 confirmed cases * 121 deaths among confirmed cases ([[case fatality rate]], 13.7%) * 4347 suspected cases * 377 deaths among suspected cases (case fatality rate, 8.7%) |- | style="background: yellow;"| '''[[Democratic Republic of the Congo|DR Congo]]''' * 78 confirmed cases (57 imported from Angola, 8 sylvatic, 13 autochthonous) * 16 deaths among confirmed cases (case fatality rate, 21.1%) * 2987 suspected cases * 121 deaths among suspected cases (case fatality rate, 4.0%) ({{smaller|[[Sylvatic]] cases are not considered part of the outbreak.}})
|- |style="background: #7b7bff;"|'''[[Kenya]]''' * 2 confirmed cases |- | '''[[People's Republic of China|China]]''' (not on map) * 11 confirmed cases |} [[File:Epidemic curve from the WHO Situation Report yellow fever in Angola, 15 September 2016.png|thumb|Epidemic curve from the WHO Situation Report yellow fever in Angola, 23 September 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 23 September 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/23-september-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=25 September 2016}}</ref>]]
[[File:YFcasesbyagegroupAngola2016.png|thumb|Yellow fever cases by age group in Angola, from 5 December 2015 to 4 August 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Situation Report: Yellow fever outbreak in Angola, 5 August 2016|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/yellow-fever/sitreps/item/8885-situation-report-yellow-fever-outbreak-in-angola-5-august-2016.html|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>]]
[[File:Line graph of confirmed cases and deaths (cumulative) in the 2016 epidemic of yellow fever in Angola as of 21 July 2016.png|thumb|Confirmed cases and deaths (cumulative) in the 2016 epidemic of yellow fever in Angola as of 21 July 2016<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 21 July 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/21-july-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=23 July 2016}}</ref>]]
On 20 January 2016, the health minister of [[Angola]] reported 23 cases of [[yellow fever]] with 7 deaths among Eritrean and Congolese citizens living in Angola in Viana municipality, a suburb of the capital of [[Luanda]]. The first cases (hemorrhagic fever suspected as being yellow fever) were reported in Eritrean visitors beginning on 5 December 2015 and confirmed by the [[Pasteur Institute|Pasteur WHO reference laboratory]] in [[Dakar]], Senegal in January.<ref>{{cite web|title=Situation report: Yellow fever outbreak in Angola, 14 March 2016|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/yellow-fever/sitreps/item/8440-sitrep-yellow-fever-outbreak-in-angola-14-march-2016.html|website=www.afro.who.int|accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (16): Angola 2016-02-27 10:11:59 Archive Number: 20160227.4053826 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4053826|website=Pro-MED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> The outbreak was classified as an urban cycle of [[Yellow fever#Transmission|yellow fever transmission]], which can spread rapidly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (18): Angola|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4090378|website=Pro-MED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref> A preliminary finding that the strain of the yellow fever virus was closely related to a strain identified in a 1971 outbreak in Angola was confirmed in August 2016.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Grobbelaar|first1=AA|last2=Weyer|first2=J|last3=Moolla|first3=N|last4=Jansen van Vuren|first4=P|last5=Moises|first5=F|last6=Paweska|first6=JT|title=Resurgence of Yellow Fever in Angola, 2015-2016.|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|date=15 October 2016|volume=22|issue=10|pmid=27536787|url=http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/22/10/16-0818_article|accessdate=21 August 2016|doi=10.3201/eid2210.160818|pmc=5038398|pages=1854–1855}}</ref> Moderators from [[ProMED-mail]] stressed the importance of initiating a vaccination campaign immediately to prevent further spread. The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] classified the outbreak as Watch Level 2 (Practice Enhanced Precautions) on 7 April 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow Fever in Angola|url=http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/yellow-fever-angola|website=Traveler's Health|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|accessdate=8 April 2016}}</ref> The WHO declared it a grade 2 event on its emergency response framework having moderate public health consequences.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (40): Angola, WHO|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4158727|website=Pro-MED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref>
At an emergency committee meeting in Geneva, Switzerland on 19 May 2016, the WHO declared that the outbreak was serious and might continue to spread, but decided not to declare a [[public health emergency of international concern]] (PHEIC).<ref>{{cite web|title=Meeting of the Emergency Committee under the International Health Regulations (2005) concerning Yellow Fever|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2016/ec-yellow-fever/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 May 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jr|first1=Donald G. Mcneil|title=W.H.O. Calls Yellow Fever in Africa ‘Serious Concern’|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/20/health/who-yellow-fever-africa.html|website=The New York Times|accessdate=19 May 2016|date=19 May 2016}}</ref> On 30 May, [[Margaret Chan]], director-general of WHO published a commentary on the bold action needed to prevent further spread of this [[Control of Communicable Diseases Manual|important communicable disease]] that caused many [[History of yellow fever|historically significant epidemics]] that took [[List of famous people who caught yellow fever|many lives]] in previous centuries.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Chan|first1=Margaret|title=Yellow fever: the resurgence of a forgotten disease|url=http://who.int/mediacentre/commentaries/yellow-fever/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=4 June 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref> On 8 June the [[International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies]] called for a scale-up in the response because of the lack of vaccine and other limitations amid the continuing spread of the outbreak.<ref>{{cite web|title=Red Cross calls for immediate scale-up in response to deadly yellow fever outbreak in Angola - IFRC|url=http://www.ifrc.org/en/news-and-media/press-releases/africa/angola/red-cross-calls-for-immediate-scale-up-in-response-to-deadly-yellow-fever-outbreak-in-angola/|website=www.ifrc.org|accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref> On 12 August 2016, Dr. Daniel R Lucey, a ProMED mail consultant, wrote an open letter to Dr. Chan requesting that the WHO emergency committee be reconvened to consider a PHEIC because of the continued spread of the disease in DR Congo, the lack of sufficient vaccine, and concern that it may be spreading into the [[Republic of the Congo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (92): WHO, Angola, Congo DR, letter to WHO|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4415083|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> On 31 August, the decision to not declare a PHEIC was re-confirmed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Second meeting of the Emergency Committee under the International Health Regulations (2005) concerning yellow fever|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2016/yellow-fever-second-ec/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=1 September 2016}}</ref> By 2 September 2016, WHO announced there had been no new cases in either Angola or DR Congo in over a month due to a massive vaccination campaign.<ref>{{cite web|title=Millions protected in Africa’s largest-ever emergency yellow fever vaccination campaign|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2016/africa-yellowfever-vaccination/en/|website=World Health Organization. 2 September 2016|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> On 25 November 2016, WHO announced that four months had passed without a new case. The last case in Angola was on 23 June and the last case in DR Congo was on 12 July. Dr Matshidiso Moeti, WHO Regional Director for Africa, stated: "The current battle against yellow fever in Angola and the Democratic Republic of the Congo is coming to a close, ... But the broader war against the disease is just getting started."<ref>{{cite web|title=Winning the war against yellow fever|url=http://www.who.int/features/2016/winning-the-war-against-yellow-fever/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref> ProMED-mail moderator Tom Yuill noted that maintaining vaccination coverage in the two countries will be the next challenge. Approximately 30 million people were vaccinated in the two countries.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (110): Angola, Congo DR, WHO|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4657067|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=28 November 2016}}</ref>
==Spread within Angola==
By early February, suspected cases were being reported from [[Provinces of Angola|southern Huila province]], about a 1000 kilometers south, and the provinces of Bié, Benguela, Cunene, Cabinda, Hula, Huambo, Malange, Kwanza Sul, Uige, Zaire and Kwanza Norte.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (16): Angola 2016-02-27 10:11:59 Archive Number: 20160227.4053826 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4053826|website=Pro-MED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> As of 9 March 2016, the WHO reported that there were 65 confirmed cases, 813 suspected cases, and 138 deaths in Angola.<ref>{{cite web|title=Angola immunizes 6.7 million people against yellow fever|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/media-centre/pressreleases/item/8413-angola-immunizes-67-million-people-against-yellow-fever.html|website=WHO Regional Office for Africa|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> On 22 March, WHO reported that cases had occurred in 6 of the 18 provinces of Angola, and that transmission was ongoing. Suspected and confirmed cases totaled 1,132, with 375 cases laboratory confirmed and 168 deaths.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow Fever – Angola|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/22-march-2016-yellow-fever-angola/en/|website=Emergencies preparedness, response|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=23 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Angola grapples with worst yellow fever outbreak in 30 years|url=http://who.int/features/2016/angola-worst-yellow-fever/en/|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref> The situation report of 28 October 2016 reported the most recent number of suspected cases and laboratory-confirmed cases; total deaths and [[case fatality rate]]s, with suspected and confirmed cases.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/28-october-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=17 December 2016}}</ref> Local, or [[Transmission (medicine)|autochthonous]], transmission had been reported in 12 provinces as of 28 October. Confirmed cases had been reported in 16 of 18 provinces. No new cases were reported during July.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (92): WHO, Angola, Congo DR, letter to WHO|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4415083|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> The WHO congratulated the Angolan government on its effort to contain the outbreak.<ref>{{cite news|title=Angola: WHO Congratulates Angola On Its Commitment to Yellow Fever Control|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201607170196.html|accessdate=17 July 2016|publisher=Allafrica|date=17 July 2016}}</ref>
==Spread to neighboring African countries==
On 22 March April 2016, the WHO was notified of 21 deaths from yellow fever in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]], some in a province that borders Angola.<ref>{{cite news|title=Congo Records 21 Yellow Fever Deaths|url=https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2016/04/12/world/africa/ap-af-africa-yellow-fever-deaths.html?_r=0|accessdate=12 April 2016|work=The New York Times|date=12 April 2016}}</ref> As of 31 May, 700 suspected cases and 63 deaths had been reported to WHO through the national surveillance system.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever – Democratic Republic of the Congo|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/02-june-2016-yellow-fever-drc/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=4 June 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref> As of 31 May, 52 cases were laboratory confirmed by the National Institute for Biomedical Research in [[Kinshasa]] and the Pasteur Institute in Dakar. Forty-six of the 52 cases were imported from Angola; 2 were classified as autochthonous. Local transmission was still ongoing in urban areas in Angola and DR Congo. WHO classified the outbreak in DR Congo as a Grade 2 Emergency. On 30 May, the [[GAVI Alliance]] announced the launch of a mass vaccination campaign in DR Congo,<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (59): DR Congo, vaccination|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4254548|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases}}</ref> but as of 22 June, vaccine was in short supply.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Foundation|first1=Thomson Reuters|title=Congo almost runs out of yellow fever vaccine amid epidemic|url=http://news.trust.org/item/20160622123734-1sjfq/?source=fiOtherNews2|website=news.trust.org|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> On 20 June, the health minister declared the outbreak of yellow fever in three provinces, including the capital of DR Congo, Kinshasa.<ref>{{cite news|title=A yellow fever epidemic has broken out in the Congo|url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/r-congo-declares-yellow-fever-epidemic-67-recorded-cases-2016-6?r=US&IR=T|accessdate=22 June 2016|work=Business Insider}}</ref> Transmission within [[Kinshasa]] is of concern because of the large and densely packed population. As of 8 July, WHO was notified of 1798 suspected cases, with 68 confirmed cases (59 imported from Angola) and 85 deaths.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 15 July 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/15-july-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=17 July 2016}}</ref> In the WHO situation report of 23 September, the last confirmed non-sylvatic or urban case had symptom onset on 12 July.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 23 September 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/23-september-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=25 September 2016}}</ref>
On 17 March, two cases, including one death, were reported in Kenya, imported from Angola.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (24): Kenya ex Angola 2016-03-18 18:40:36|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4104819|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> On 28 March, a [[rapid response team]] was deployed into Uganda, where there was ongoing transmission unrelated to the Angola outbreak.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever – Uganda - WHO {{!}} Regional Office for Africa|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/clusters-a-programmes/dpc/epidemic-a-pandemic-alert-and-response/outbreak-news/4921-yellow-fever-uganda.html|website=www.afro.who.int|accessdate=8 May 2016}}</ref> According to WHO, cases had been exported from Angola to China, DR Congo, and Kenya, as of 4 May 2016. One case had been reported in [[Namibia]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=8 May 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref>
ProMED mail reported that as of 3 Aug 2016, 193 cases of yellow fever were suspected in the [[Republic of the Congo]], with 4 cases having tested positive for yellow fever IgM.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (92): WHO, Angola, Congo DR, letter to WHO|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4415083|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref> Further proliferation of the mosquito vector had been expected with the advent of the rainy season, which can begin before the end of September.
==Spread to China via air travel==
On 13 March 2016, the Chinese government confirmed that a 32-year-old male Chinese citizen who had been in Angola had developed yellow fever on return.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - China: ex Angola, 1st case in Asia 2016-03-13 16:14:53|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4089857|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow Fever – China|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/29-march-2016-yellow-fever-china/en/|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> The case was the first imported yellow fever case in China in history. [[Yellow fever#Epidemiology|Yellow fever]] has never appeared in Asia even though the mosquito vector is present.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Vainio|first1=J|last2=Cutts|first2=F|title=Yellow Fever|date=1998|publisher=World Health Organization|url=http://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/64455}}</ref> Additional cases were later reported in people who first had symptoms while in Luanda.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - China (03): ex Angola 2016-03-19 22:06:08 20160319.4106312 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4106312|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref> [[ProMED-mail]] moderator [[John "Jack" P. Woodall|Jack Woodall]] warned that "spread could make the Ebola and Zika epidemics look like picnics in the park!" and that "international action should start now."<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - China: ex Angola, 1st case in Asia 2016-03-13 16:14:53|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4089857|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> Chinese authorities strengthened [[Thermography|thermal imaging]] at airports to detect passengers with elevated body temperatures.<ref>{{cite news|title=Guangdong strengthens monitoring of body temperature on passengers (2)|url=http://en.people.cn/n3/2016/0216/c90882-9017479-2.html|accessdate=20 March 2016|publisher=Xinhua/Liu Dawei|date=16 February 2016}}</ref> A Chinese medical team deployed to Angola vaccinated 120 Chinese nationals as part of epidemic research.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (32): Angola 2016-03-29 20:31:42 Archive Number|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4126331|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> More than 250,000 [[Chinese people in Angola|Chinese nationals live in Angola]]. On 8 April 2016, ten North Korean workers in Angola were reported to have died of yellow fever.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Herald|first1=The Korea|title=N. Korean workers die of yellow fever in Angola: RFA|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160408000773|website=www.koreaherald.com|accessdate=10 April 2016}}</ref>
On 25 March 2016, a case was reported in [[Fujian]] Province, in a woman who returned from Angola on 12 March.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - China (05) ex Angola 2016-03-25 17:56:49 Archive Number: Archive Number: 20160325.4119422 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4119422|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> Fujian is within the predicted distribution of [[Aedes aegypti]], the mosquito that transmits the yellow fever virus to humans. [[Mosquito-borne diseases]] can become endemic in a new geographic area when local mosquitoes become infected by feeding on an imported case.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zika Virus Spreads to New Areas — Region of the Americas, May 2015–January 2016|url=https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6503e1.htm|website=Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report|publisher=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|accessdate=26 March 2016}}</ref> Between 18 March and 22 April, the WHO was notified of 11 imported cases in China.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow Fever – China|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/22-april-2016-yellow-fever-china/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=1 May 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref> Officials in Asia were concerned about the threat of yellow fever.<ref>{{cite news|title=Yellow Fever: Southeast Asia’s next great outbreak? {{!}} GovInsider|url=https://govinsider.asia/digital-gov/yellow-fever-southeast-asias-next-great-outbreak/|accessdate=4 July 2016|date=4 July 2016}}</ref>
==Potential for further international spread==
On 28 March, ProMED-mail moderators [[John "Jack" P. Woodall|Jack Woodall]] and Tom Yuill issued a strongly worded warning on the threat of yellow fever for countries that have endemic dengue fever (and thus the mosquito vector of yellow fever and dengue fever, [[Aedes aegypti]]), and particularly for countries in Asia, where until recently yellow fever has never appeared. Urban populations and mosquito-infested slums in Asia and Africa are much larger than in the past.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Butler|first1=Declan|title=Fears rise over yellow fever’s next move|url=http://www.nature.com/news/fears-rise-over-yellow-fever-s-next-move-1.19722|website=Nature|accessdate=29 May 2016|pages=155–156|doi=10.1038/532155a|date=14 April 2016}}</ref> A commentary and accompanying article published in May stressed the potential for spread to Asia by international air travel.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Woodall|first1=J.P.|last2=Yuill|first2=T.M.|title=Why is the yellow fever outbreak in Angola a ‘threat to the entire world’?|journal=International Journal of Infectious Diseases|volume=0|issue=0|doi=10.1016/j.ijid.2016.05.001|url=http://www.ijidonline.com/article/S1201-9712(16)31044-X/fulltext|language=English|issn=1201-9712|pages=96–97|year=2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wasserman|first1=Sean|last2=Tambyah|first2=Paul Anantharajah|last3=Lim|first3=Poh Lian|title=Yellow fever cases in Asia: primed for an epidemic|journal=International Journal of Infectious Diseases|volume=0|issue=0|doi=10.1016/j.ijid.2016.04.025|url=http://www.ijidonline.com/article/S1201-9712(16)31043-8/fulltext|language=English|issn=1201-9712|pages=98–103|year=2016}}</ref> Other parts of the world where yellow fever is present but usually in the quiescent jungle cycle, and where there is regular air travel, such as Brazil, may also be vulnerable.<ref>{{cite web|title=Opinion: Who's Afraid of Yellow Fever? Why We Should Be |url=http://riotimesonline.com/brazil-news/opinion-editorial/opinion-whos-afraid-of-yellow-fever-why-we-should-be/|website=The Rio Times|accessdate=24 April 2016}}</ref> They stressed that [[Yellow fever vaccine#Manufacture and global supply|world stocks of 7 million doses of vaccine]] have been exhausted in the vaccination campaign against the outbreak in Angola. If yellow fever spread to the 18 countries in Asia where the mosquito vector is present, more than 2 billion people would be at risk. They stated: "Apocalyptic forecasts of the numbers of fatalities from Ebola turned out to be wildly wrong, and we can hope that will again be the case here, but given the way [[Zika virus outbreak (2015–present)|Zika]] has exploded in the Western hemisphere, we can't count on it." <ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - countries with dengue: alert 2016-03-28 20:39:56 Archive Number: Archive Number: 20160328.4123983|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4123983|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> CDC said they could not assist as much in the outbreak because all its experts were involved in efforts against the [[Zika virus outbreak (2015–present)|Zika virus outbreak in the Americas]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Jr|first1=Donald G. Mcneil|title=Yellow Fever Outbreak in Angola Strains Health Organizations|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/05/health/yellow-fever-outbreak-angola-who.html|accessdate=7 April 2016|work=The New York Times|date=4 April 2016}}</ref> Starting on 26 April, ProMED-mail issued a series of posts on pre-planning information for countries at risk of importation of yellow fever, covering vaccination, mosquito control, quarantine and personal protection measures.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - pre-planning for at-risk countries: vaccine|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4182666|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=26 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - pre-planning for at-risk countries (02): mosquito control|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4183615|website=www.promedmail.org|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=27 April 2016}}</ref>
In an article in ''[[JAMA (journal)|JAMA]]'' on 9 May 2016, the Georgetown University Law Center called for the WHO to form an emergency committee to determine whether a [[public health emergency of international concern]] should be declared.<ref>{{cite web|title=A yellow fever epidemic: A new global health emergency?|url=http://jama.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=2522030|website=JAMA|accessdate=10 May 2016|doi=10.1001/jama.2016.6606|date=9 May 2016}}</ref> On 12 May, the [[European Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection]] of the [[European Union]] announced plans to send a team of the [[European Medical Corps]] to Angola on a two-week mission to help control the outbreak and assess the risk of further spread outside Angola.<ref>{{cite web|title=EU sends new medical corps team to Angola yellow fever outbreak|url=http://www.euractiv.com/section/development-policy/news/eu-sends-new-medical-corps-team-to-angola-yellow-fever-outbreak/|website=EurActiv.com|accessdate=13 May 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref> The medical corps was formed after the [[West African Ebola virus epidemic|Ebola outbreak in West Africa]] that began in 2013, and the mission to Angola was its first deployment. The team included "emergency medical teams, public health and medical coordination experts, mobile biosafety laboratories, medical evacuation planes and logistical support teams".<ref>{{cite web|title=European Commission - PRESS RELEASES - Press release - EU launches new European Medical Corps to respond faster to emergencies|url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-16-263_en.htm|website=europa.eu|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Mobile labs deliver faster yellow fever test results|url=http://www.who.int/features/2016/yellow-fever-labs/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=15 August 2016}}</ref>
Efforts to prevent international spread are confounded by the practice of selling falsified [[Carte Jaune|yellow fever vaccination certificates]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (06): Nigeria, fake cards|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/3977690|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> The fake cards are sold to people who are required to have proof of vaccination after travel to areas where yellow fever is endemic. On 11 February 2016, the Pasteur Institute (WHO) in Senegal warned of fake yellow fever vaccine on the international market.<ref>{{cite web|title= Yellow fever - Africa (15): Angola, fake vaccine, SE Asia, WHO alert 2016-02-24 13:32:43 Archive Number: 20160224.4047041 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4047041|website=Pro-MED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref>
==Vaccination campaign== [[File:Yellow fever vaccination recommendations for Africa, 2015.png|thumb|Vaccination recommendations for the “yellow fever belt” of Africa, 2015<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever – Uganda|url=http://www.who.int/csr/don/02-may-2016-yellow-fever-uganda/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=3 May 2016|language=en-GB}}</ref>]]
With help from the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), the Angolan Ministry of Health began a campaign of [[Yellow fever#Prevention|preventive measures]] including vector control and vaccination in Viana in the first week of February.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (09): Angola 2016-02-08 09:32:03 Archive Number 20160208.4003005|url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4003005|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> However, the minister reported that the government had enough vaccine for routine vaccination, but not enough to contain an outbreak.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever - Africa (07): Angola (LU) RFI 2016-02-01 14:32:42 Archive Number: 20160201.3984228 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/3984228|website=Pro-MED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> The WHO was supporting the Angolan government in immunization of 6.7 million people in Luanda province with the aim of vaccinating at least 80% of the population at risk of infection.<ref>{{cite web|title=Angola immunizes 6.7 million people against yellow fever|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/media-centre/pressreleases/item/8413-angola-immunizes-67-million-people-against-yellow-fever.html|website=WHO Regional Office for Africa|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=17 March 2016}}</ref> The vaccine supply began to run low by late March, with the director of the CDC, Tom Friedman, warning that "It's possible we could run out of vaccine."<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever vaccine shortage as outbreak in Angola spreads|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2016/03/25/health/yellow-fever-vaccine-shortage-angola/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=29 March 2016}}</ref> The goal of the vaccination campaign in Luanda province was to vaccinate 88 percent of the population (5 804 475 of 6 583 216); ProMED reported that the total national stock of yellow fever vaccine as of 29 Mar 2016 was 1 032 970 doses.<ref>{{cite web|title= Yellow fever - Africa (34): Angola, WHO 2016-04-04 12:10:59 09:32:03 Archive Number 20160404.4137096 |url=http://www.promedmail.org/post/4137096|website=ProMED-mail|publisher=International Society for Infectious Diseases|accessdate=5 April 2016}}</ref> As of 10 April 2016, almost 6 million people had been vaccinated in Luanda.<ref>{{cite web|title=Situation Report: Yellow fever outbreak in Angola, 10 April 2016|url=http://www.afro.who.int/pt/yellow-fever/sitreps/item/8508-situation-report-yellow-fever-outbreak-in-angola-11-april-2016.html|website=www.afro.who.int|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref> On 19 April, the WHO reported that the campaign had been extended into the provinces of Huambo and Benguela where local transmission was reported.<ref>{{cite web|title=Angola extends yellow fever vaccination campaign to Huambo and Benguela provinces|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/media-centre/pressreleases/item/8528-angola-extends-yellow-fever-vaccination-campaign-to-huambo-and-benguela-provinces.html|website=www.afro.who.int|accessdate=21 April 2016}}</ref> On 23 May, the WHO reported that 7.8 million people (91.1%) had been vaccinated in the three provinces.<ref>{{cite web|title=Situation Report: Yellow fever outbreak in Angola, 23 May 2016|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/yellow-fever/sitreps/item/8660-situation-report-yellow-fever-outbreak-in-angola-23-may-2016.html|website=www.afro.who.int|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> On 23 May, the WHO announced that coverage of an additional 2.7 million people in 5 provinces had reached 55% after 6 days of vaccination.<ref>{{cite web|title=Situation Report: Yellow fever outbreak in Angola, 23 May 2016|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/yellow-fever/sitreps/item/8660-situation-report-yellow-fever-outbreak-in-angola-23-may-2016.html|website=www.afro.who.int|accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> A second phase of the vaccination campaign in Angola was announced in the situation report of 23 September.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 23 September 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/23-september-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=25 September 2016}}</ref>
On June 22, the WHO announced plans to launch a pre-emptive emergency vaccination campaign beginning in July in highly trafficked borders areas of Angola and DR Congo and in densely populated Kinshasa.<ref>{{cite web|title=Launch of emergency vaccination campaigns on the DR Congo and Angola border|url=http://www.afro.who.int/en/media-centre/pressreleases/item/8753-launch-of-emergency-vaccination-campaigns-on-the-dr-congo-and-angola-border.html|accessdate=25 June 2016}}</ref> On 20 July, the DR Congo government launched a campaign to deliver 1 million doses of yellow fever vaccine over 10 days.<ref>{{cite news|title=Democratic Republic of Congo launches yellow fever vaccination drive|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-yellowfever-congo-idUSKCN1001TL|accessdate=21 July 2016|work=Reuters|date=20 July 2016}}</ref> In August, the WHO with partners including [[Médecins sans Frontières]], [[International Federation of the Red Cross]] and [[UNICEF]] launched another campaign to vaccinate more than 14 million people in Angola and DR Congo.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mass vaccination campaign to protect millions against yellow fever in Angola and Democratic Republic of the Congo|url=http://www.who.int/features/2016/yellow-fever-mass-vaccination-campaign/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref> On 2 September, WHO announced that the campaign to vaccinate the 7.7 million residents of [[Kinshasa]], the capitol of DR Congo, had been completed in record time and before the beginning of the rainy season in September when the mosquito population expands.<ref>{{cite web|title=Millions protected in Africa’s largest-ever emergency yellow fever vaccination campaign|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2016/africa-yellowfever-vaccination/en/|website=World Health Organization. 2 September 2016|accessdate=3 September 2016}}</ref> The campaign required 10 million specialized syringes and training of 40,000 vaccinators, using the dose sparing strategy of 1/5 the usual dose. In the situation report of 23 September, the WHO announced that a pre-emptive vaccination campaign was being planned for the [[Republic of Congo]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Yellow fever situation report 23 September 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/situation-reports/23-september-2016/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=25 September 2016}}</ref>
One million doses of 6 million shipped in February went missing, resulting in shortages to fight the spreading epidemic in DR Congo.<ref>{{cite news|title=UN bungles response to Africa's yellow fever outbreak|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/c5be7d71b0cb4c99a05940f5adfc7166/ap-investigation-1-million-vaccines-vanished-angola#|accessdate=5 August 2016}}</ref> The estimated shortage was 22 million doses as of August 2016. Vaccine and syringes might have been diverted for sale in private markets.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Times|first1=Los Angeles|title=Amid worst yellow fever outbreak in decades, 1 million vaccines go missing|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/la-fg-yellow-fever-vaccines-disppear-20160804-snap-story.html|accessdate=15 August 2016|work=latimes.com}}</ref>
If the epidemic were to spread, particularly into Asia, the [[Yellow fever vaccine|global supply of vaccine]] would have been insufficient to protect the millions of people that would need to be vaccinated to curb an epidemic.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Merelli|first1=Annalisa|title=The world was running short of yellow fever vaccines—and millions were at risk|url=http://qz.com/539417/the-world-is-running-short-of-yellow-fever-vaccines-and-millions-are-at-risk/|website=Quartz|accessdate=17 April 2016|language=en-US}}</ref> As an emergency measure, experts suggested the dose-sparing strategy to extend existing supplies of vaccine, which the WHO could provide under the Emergency Use Assessment and Listing procedure.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Yellow fever vaccine supply: a possible solution - The Lancet|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(16)30195-7 | volume=387 | year=2016|journal=The Lancet|pages=1599–1600 | last1 = Monath | first1 = Thomas P | last2 = Woodall | first2 = Jack P | last3 = Gubler | first3 = Duane J | last4 = Yuill | first4 = Thomas M | last5 = Mackenzie | first5 = John S | last6 = Martins | first6 = Reinaldo M | last7 = Reiter | first7 = Paul | last8 = Heymann | first8 = David L}}</ref> The WHO agreed to the recommendation, authorizing one-fifth the usual dose during the ongoing outbreak in Angola and DR Congo, but [[International Health Regulations|international health regulations]] still apply to travelers, who must obtain the full dose to quality for the [[Carte Jaune|certificate of vaccination]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Lower doses of yellow fever vaccine could be used in emergencies|url=http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/statements/2016/yellow-fever-vaccine/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=19 June 2016}}</ref>
==Response to the epidemic== In June 2016, a WHO representative in Luanda said that the initial investigation of the outbreak in December was thrown off course because the first cases in December 2015—the sick Eritrean visitors—had what were later identified as fake yellow fever vaccination certificates. All had been to the same restaurant, so food poisoning was initially suspected as the cause of the mystery illness.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Times|first1=Los Angeles|title=Yellow fever outbreak: Health officials to weigh declaring global emergency|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/global-development/la-fg-global-yellow-fever-snap-story.html|website=latimes.com|accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref> It was more than a month before blood samples from the Eritreans reached the Pasteur Institute lab and yellow fever was recognized. Public health experts identified that as one factor that delayed the response to the outbreak, which came close to being a much larger disaster, if vaccine supplies had not been successfully raised in time, or the disease had spread to other countries and continents.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Calisher|first1=CH|last2=Woodall|first2=JP|title=Yellow Fever-More a Policy and Planning Problem than a Biological One.|journal=Emerging Infectious Diseases|date=October 2016|volume=22|issue=10|pages=1859–60|pmid=27479749|doi=10.3201/eid2210.160875|pmc=5038394}}</ref> The concurrent [[2015–16 Zika virus epidemic|Zika outbreak]] drew attention away from a potentially far more serious epidemic of yellow fever.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Jr|first1=Donald G. Mcneil|title=Yellow Fever Epidemic in Africa Shows Gaps in Vaccine Pipeline|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/05/health/yellow-fever-africa-vaccine.html?_r=0|website=The New York Times|accessdate=7 December 2016|date=5 December 2016}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== {{Portal|Medicine|Viruses}} {{Wikivoyage|Yellow fever}} * {{cite web|title=Supercourse: Epidemiology, the Internet and Global Health|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~super1/|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=29 March 2016}} * {{cite web|title=YELLOW FEVER in ASIA|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~super1/lecture/lec54261/index.htm|website=Supercourse|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=29 March 2016}} * {{cite web|title=Timeline: Yellow fever outbreak 2016|url=http://www.who.int/emergencies/yellow-fever/mediacentre/timeline/en/|website=World Health Organization|accessdate=15 June 2016}} * {{cite web|title=Fighting yellow fever in the Democratic Republic of the Congo – in pictures|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2016/aug/26/fighting-yellow-fever-in-the-democratic-republic-of-congo-in-pictures|accessdate=28 August 2016}} * {{cite web|title=Resetting the yellow fever strategy|url=http://www.who.int/csr/disease/yellowfev/eye-strategy/en/|accessdate=18 September 2016}}
<!--- Categories ---> [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:2016 in Angola]] [[Category:Yellow fever]] [[Category:Health in Angola]] [[Category:21st-century epidemics]]

The '''Adjective Check List''' ('''ACL''') is a psychological assessment containing 300 [[Adjective|adjectives]] used to identify common [[psychological trait]]s.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Adjective Check List Manual|last=Gough|first=H.G.|last2=Heilbrun, Jr.|first2=A.B.|publisher=CPP, Inc.|year=2007|isbn=|edition=1983|location=Palo Alto, CA|pages=}}</ref> The ACL was constructed by [[Harrison G. Gough]] and Alfred B. Heilbrun, Jr. with the goal to assess psychological traits of an individual.<ref>Gough, H. G. (1960). The Adjective Check List as a personalty assessment research technique. ''Psychological Reports, 6,'' 107-122.</ref> The ACL measures 37 scales within 5 categories: [[modus operandi]] (4 scales), need (15 scales), topical (9 scales), [[transactional analysis]] (5 scales), and origence-intellectence (4 scales).<ref name="mindgarden" /> To complete the ACL, respondents select the adjectives that they believe describe themselves (or someone else). Any number of items may be selected from the list of adjectives. In this way, the results are customized to include only those adjectives salient to the individual being assessed. The ACL takes between 10-15 minutes to complete and may be administered to individuals, groups, or used by [[researcher]]s to describe study participants.<ref name=mindgarden>{{cite web|url=http://www.mindgarden.com/products/acl.htm|title=The Adjective Check List |accessdate=8 May 2010}}</ref> The ACL is protected by [[Copyright|copyright law]], published by Consulting Psychologists Press, and distributed by Mind Garden, Inc.
The ACL was first developed in the early days of the Institute of Personality Assessment and Research at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref name=":0" /> It has been used since 1952 by many psychologists worldwide and is one of the 100 most frequently used and cited tests in psychology.<ref name=":0" />
== ACL Research and Uses == "The ACL offers several advantages. It is self-administering, may be completed in 10 to 15 minutes, arouses little resistance or anxiety, and has proved useful in studies of highly effective persons in occupations other than politics such as architecture, mathematics, law, medicine, and management.
"Further, as a multidimensional instrument, which taps several domains of personality, the ACL affords an appraisal of positive as well as negative factors in human behavior, thus avoiding the frequently found preoccupation with psychopathological bases of political activity. Additionally, as an established standardized, and quantitative assessment procedure, the ACL reduces the problems of reliability and comparability entailed in studies relying on interviews or on ad hoc, limited use or abbreviated personality measures” (Constantini & Craik, 1980, p. 645).<ref>Constantini, E., & Craik, K. H. (1980). Personality and politicians: California party leaders, 1960-1976. ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology'', ''38''(4), 641.-661.</ref>
"We propose that the Gough-Heilbrun Adjective Check List is another broad-range instrument with considerable promise as a general cross-cultural research tool. The argument is based on: the nature of the task, which seems appropriate in many cultural settings; the versatility of the method in addressing a variety of research questions; the fact that the instrument has been translated into many different languages; and the successful use of the method in recent cross-cultural studies" (Williams & Best, 1983, p. 164).<ref>Williams, J. E., & Best, D. L. (1983). The Gough-Heilbrun Adjective Check List as a cross-cultural research tool. In J.B Deregowski, S. Dziurawiec, & R.C. Annis (Eds.) ''Expiscations in cross-cultural psychology.'' Netherlands: Swets & Zeitlinger B.V.</ref>
== ACL Success Factors at Work<ref name="mindgarden" /> == The ACL scales were realigned in 2012 by Rob Devine in consultation with Gough to highlight how collections of characteristics, skills, and competencies impact success at work. This realignment, called Success Factors at Work, uses 30 of the original 37 ACL scales and assigns each to one of six Work Success Factors which have proven to be central and important to success at work. The six Work Success Factors are: * Managing Self * Thinking and Deciding * Getting Things Done * Managing Work * Working with People * Leading People
== ACL Scales == The ACL consists of 37 scales within 5 categories: modus operandi (4 scales), need (15 scales), topical (9 scales), transactional analysis (5 scales), and origence-intellectence (4 scales).
=== Modus Operandi Scales === The Modus Operandi Scales assess ways in which the individual approached the task of describing themselves (or someone else). * '''Number Checked:''' Total number of adjectives checked. * '''Favorable:''' The number of favorable (socially desirable) adjectives checked. * '''Unfavorable:''' The number of unfavorable (socially undesirable) adjectives checked. * '''Communality:''' Correspondence of responses to the pattern of checking typically found among people-in-general.
=== Need Scales === The Need Scales assess an individual's psychological needs or wants. These were identified as important in [[Henry Murray|Henry A. Murray]]'s [[Murray's system of needs|Need-Press Theory of Personality]].<ref>Murray, H.A. (1938). ''Explorations in Personality.'' New York: Oxford University Press.</ref> * '''Achievement:''' To strive to be outstanding in pursuits of socially recognized significance. * '''Dominance:''' To seek and maintain a role as leader in groups, or to be influential and controlling in individual relationships. * '''Endurance:''' To persist in any task undertaken. * '''Order:''' To place special emphasis on neatness, organization, and planning in one's activities. * '''Intraception:''' To engage in attempts to understand one's own behavior or the behavior of others. * '''Nurturance:''' To engage in behaviors that provide material or emotional benefits to others. * '''Affiliation:''' To seek and maintain numerous personal friendships. * '''Heterosexuality:''' To seek the company of and derive emotional satisfaction from interactions with peers of the opposite sex. * '''Exhibition:''' To behave in such a way as to elicit the immediate attention of others. * '''Autonomy:''' To act independently of others or of social values and expectations. * '''Aggression:''' To engage in behaviors that attack or hurt others. * '''Change:''' To seek novelty of experience and avoid routine. * '''Succorance:''' To solicit sympathy, affection, or emotional support from others. * '''Abasement:''' To express feelings of inferiority through self-criticism, guilt, or social impotence. * '''Deference:''' To seek and maintain subordinate roles in relationships with others.
=== Topical Scales === The Topical Scales assess a diverse set of attributes, potentialities, and role characteristics. * '''Counseling Readiness:''' Readiness to accept counseling or professional advice in regard to personal problems, psychological difficulties, and the like.<ref>Heilbrun, A. B., Jr., & Sullivan, D. J. (1962). The prediction of counseling readiness. ''Personnel and Guidance Journal, 41'', 112-117.</ref> * '''Self-Control:''' The extent to which self-control is imposed, and valued. * '''Self-Confidence:''' Self-confidence, poise, and self-assurance. * '''Personal Adjustment:''' Good adjustment in the sense of the ability to cope with situational and interpersonal demands and a feeling of efficacy. * '''Ideal Self:''' Strong sense of personal worth; or, harmony between what one is and what one wants to be. * '''Creative Personality:''' The desire to do and think differently from the norm, and a talent for originality.<ref>Gough, H. G. 1979. A creative personality scale for the Adjective Check List. ''Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 37,'' 1398-1405.</ref> * '''Military Leader:''' Steadiness, self-discipline, good judgment of the kind required in positions of military (or related) leadership.<ref>MacKinnon, D. W., Crutchfield, R. S., Barron, F., Block, J., Gough, H. G., & Harris, R. E. (1958). ''An assessment study of Air Force officers, Part 1: Design of the study and description of the variables'' (USAF WADC Tech. Rep. 58-9, ASTIA Doc. No. AD 151 050). Lackland Air Force Base, Texas: Personnel Laboratory.</ref> * '''Masculine:''' Role-qualities such as ambition, assertiveness, and initiative associated with everyday notions of masculinity. * '''Femininity:''' Role-qualities such as helpfulness, sympathy, and affection associated with everyday notions of femininity.
=== Transactional Analysis Scales === The Transactional Analysis Scales - an Egogram - assess components of ego functioning. These were identified as important by [[Eric Berne]]'s [[Transactional analysis|Transactional Analysis]] theory of personality.<ref>Berne, E. (1961). ''Transactional analysis in psychotherapy.'' New York: Grove Press.</ref> * '''Critical Parent:''' Attitudes of evaluation, severity, and skepticism associated with the concept of a "critical parent." * '''Nurturing Parent:''' Attitudes of support, stability, and acceptance associated with the concept of a "nurturing parent." * '''Adult:''' Attitudes of independence, objectivity, and industriousness associated with the concept of a "mature adult." * '''Free Child:''' Attitudes of playfulness, impulsivity, self-centeredness associated with the concept of a "free" or very expressive child. * '''Adapted Child:''' Attitudes of deference, conformity, and self-discipline associated with the concept of an "adapted" or very dutiful child.
=== Origence-Intellectence Scales === The Origence-Intellectence Scales assess the balance between preferences for affective-emotional and rational-realistic models of functioning. These were identified as important by George S. Welsh's creativity and intelligence research.<ref>Welsh, G. S. (1975). ''Creativity and intelligence: A personality approach.'' Chapel Hill, North Carolina: Institute for Research in Social Science, University of North Carolina.</ref><ref>Welsh, G. S. (1977). Personality correlates of intelligence and creativity in gifted adolescents. In J.C. Stanley, W.C. George, & C.H. Solano (Eds.), ''The gifted and the creative: A fifty-year perspective.'' Baltimore, MD: Johns Hopkins University Press.</ref> * '''High Origence - Low Intellectence:''' Feelings and emotion (high origence) valued more highly than detachment and rationality (low intellectence). High scores suggest informality, vitality, and playfulness. * '''High Origence - High Intellectence:''' High value placed on both affect (origence) and rationality (intellectence). High scores suggest versatility, unconventionality, and individuality. * '''Low Origence - Low Intellectence:''' No particular value placed on either origence or intellectence. High scores suggest contentment, conventionality, and optimism. * '''Low Origence - High Intellectence:''' Rationality and analysis (intellectence) valued more highly than feelings and emotion (origence). High scores suggest logicality, industriousness, and cognitive clarity.
==References== <references /> [[Category:Psychological testing]] [[Category:Personality]]
{{psych-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Use British English|date=February 2018}} '''Arnold George Dominic Maran''' (16 June 1937 – 10 December 2017) was a Scottish surgeon and writer, of Italian descent. He was President of the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]] from 1997 to 2000, and has been described as "one of the world's leading medical experts on the voice".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wagnerscotland.net/newsletter9_4.html|title=Forthcoming events: The Voice Doctor|year=2005|work=Newsletter vol 9 no 4|publisher=Wagner Society of Scotland|accessdate=3 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104064644/http://www.wagnerscotland.net/newsletter9_4.html|archivedate=4 November 2013}}</ref>
He was Professor of Otolaryngology at the [[University of Edinburgh]] from 1988 to 2000.<ref name="whos">{{cite web|title=Maran, Prof. Arnold George Dominic|url=http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/10.1093/ww/9780199540884.001.0001/ww-9780199540884-e-26579|website=Who's Who 2018|publisher=Oxford UP|accessdate=12 December 2017}}</ref> In 1997 he was elected President of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh and in 2004 was awarded an honorary degree of D.Sc. by the [[University of Hong Kong]].<ref name=uhk>{{cite web|url=http://www4.hku.hk/hongrads/index.php/archive/graduate_detail/261|title=Honorary Degrees: Arnold George Dominic Maran|year=2004|publisher=University of Hong Kong|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
The textbook ''Head and Neck Surgery'' which he co-authored with [[Philip Stell]] in 1972 (Heinemann, {{ISBN|0433315709}}) was republished in 2012 as ''Stell & Maran's Textbook of Head and Neck Surgery and Oncology, Fifth Edition'' by John Watkinson and Ralph W Gilbert (CRC Press; {{ISBN|978-0-340-92916-2}}).
He also wrote books on the physiology of the human voice (''The Voice Doctor: The Story of Singing'', 2006, Book Guild: {{ISBN|978-1857769159}}); the Sicilian Mafia (''Mafia: Inside the Dark Heart'', 2008, Mainstream: {{ISBN|978-1845964573}}), drawing on an incident involving his great uncles;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/surgeon-cuts-to-heart-of-the-mob-1-1254214|title=Surgeon cuts to heart of the mob|date=27 March 2008|work=[[The Scotsman]]|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref> and an unusual [[golf]] game (''Golf at the North Pole: The Arctic and the Ancient Game'', 2013, Upfront: {{ISBN|9781780357041}}).
==Death== Arnold Maran died on 10 December 2017, aged 80.{{Where|date=February 2018}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rcsed.ac.uk/news-public-affairs/news/2017/december-2017/obituary-professor-arnold-maran|title= Obituary – Professor Arnold Maran| publisher=Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh|date=11 December 2017|accessdate=11 December 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Maran, Arnold}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Scottish medical doctors]] [[Category:Scottish surgeons]] [[Category:British otolaryngologists]] [[Category:Place of birth missing]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Edinburgh]] [[Category:Presidents of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh]]

[[File:Cephalicpre.JPG|thumb|alt=a fetus is depicted head-down and facing the mother's spine. |Normal fetal position (occiput anterior); back labour may occur if the fetus faces the opposite direction (occiput posterior).]] [[File:Birth-ball.jpg|thumb|alt=A woman kneeling in three different positions: with pillows; with pillows and a chair; with a birth ball |Back labor can be painful. Relief may be sought by trying to find a comfortable position or using a birth ball.]] '''Back labor''' (less commonly called '''posterior labor'''<ref name="posterior1">Moore, Mary Lou & Ora Strickland, ''Realities in Childbearing'', p. 398 (1978) (using term "posterior labor")</ref><ref name="elhalta">El Halta, Valerie ''[http://www.midwiferytoday.com/articles/paininback.asp Posterior Labor---A pain in the back!]'', ICAN Clarion 1996; 2(1)</ref>) is a term referring to sensations of pain or discomfort that occur in the lower back, just above the [[Coccyx|tailbone]], to a mother during [[childbirth]].<ref name="mayo1">Harms, Rogert W. [http://www.mayoclinic.org/healthy-living/labor-and-delivery/expert-answers/back-labor/faq-20058547 Does back labor really happen?], mayoclinic.com, Retrieved 8 September 2014</ref>
Back labor may be noted when the baby is face up in the birth canal (occiput posterior), and not face down, so that the back of the baby's skull ([[occiput]]) is pushed against the mother's [[sacrum]]. But back labor can also occur when the baby is not in that position.<ref name="mayo1"/> The discomfort is often noted to be intensely painful, and may not completely abate between contractions.<ref name="nursing">Klossner, N. Jayne. ''Introductory Nursing, Vol. 1'', pp. 190, 432-33 (2006)</ref> Whether back labor will occur cannot be predicted in advance. Reports of how many mothers experience back labor vary,<ref name="easing">Lieberman, Adrienne B. [https://books.google.com/books?id=vxZxksJNLgkC&pg=PA17&#v=onepage&q&f=false Easing Labor Pain: The Complete Guide to a More Comfortable and Rewarding Birth], p. 17 (1992) (This 1992 book says childhood educators typically cite 25%)</ref> though estimates in the range of 30% are common.<ref name="30one">Curtis, Glade B. & Schuler, Judith. [https://books.google.com/books?id=wfFmAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA290#v=onepage&q&f=false Your Pregnancy After 35: Revised Edition], p. 290 (2001)</ref><ref name="melzack1">Melzack, R. & D. Schaffelberg. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2953242 Low-back pain during labor], ''Am J. Obstet Gynecol.'', 1987 Apr; 156 (4):901-05 (abstract) (1987 finding that "continuous low-back pain is severe and is reported by about 33% of women during labor.")</ref>
Actions that have been suggested to ameliorate back labor include physical activity, changing positions,<ref name="simkin">Simkin, P. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20402724 The fetal occiput posterior position: state of the science and a new perspective], ''Birth'' 2010 Mar; 37(1)l 61-71</ref> back rubbing, water massage, application of hot or cold to the lower back, use of a [[birthing ball]]<ref name="ball">(25 July 2013). [http://www.allparenting.com/my-pregnancy/articles/968269/positions-and-comfort-measures-to-ease-back-labor Positions and comfort measures to easy back labor], allparenting.com</ref> and medication including an [[Epidural#Epidural analgesia during childbirth|epidural]].<ref name="mayo1"/><ref name="murkoff">Murkoff, Heidi & Sharon Mazel. ''What to Expect When You're Expecting'', p. 367-368 (4th ed. 2008)</ref> Some research has suggested that injecting sterile water into the lower back may provide pain relief, but there is no consensus that it actually helps.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Derry | first1 = S. | last2 = Straube | first2 = S. | last3 = Moore | first3 = RA. | last4 = Hancock | first4 = H. | last5 = Collins | first5 = SL. | title = Intracutaneous or subcutaneous sterile water injection compared with blinded controls for pain management in labour | journal = Cochrane Database Syst Rev | volume = 1 | issue = | pages = CD009107 | year = 2012 | doi = 10.1002/14651858.CD009107.pub2 | pmid = 22258999 | editor1-last = Derry | editor1-first = Sheena }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Presentation (obstetrics)]]
