revision.text:
'''Barrier nursing''' is a largely archaic term for a set of stringent [[infection control]] techniques used in [[nursing]]. The aim of barrier nursing is to protect medical staff against infection by patients and also protect patients with highly [[infectious disease]]s from spreading their pathogens to other non-infected people.
Barrier nursing was created as a means to maximize [[Isolation (health care)|isolation care]]. Since it is impossible to isolate a patient from society and medical staff while still providing care, there are often compromises made when it comes to treating infectious patients. Barrier nursing is a method to regulate and minimize the number and severity of compromises being made in [[Isolation (health care)|isolation care]], while also preventing the disease from spreading.<ref name=":02">{{cite journal|title=Barrier Nursing|journal=BMJ|volume=1|issue=5492|year=1966|pages=876–876|issn=0959-8138|doi=10.1136/bmj.1.5492.876}}</ref>
== History & usage == '''Barrier nursing''' started off as a term used by the Centre for Disease Control (CDC) to describe early [[infection control]] methods in the late 1800s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gammon|first=J.|date=March 26 – April 8, 1998 |title=A review of the development of isolation precautions|journal=British Journal of Nursing (Mark Allen Publishing)|volume=7|issue=6|pages=307–310|doi=10.12968/bjon.1998.7.6.5727|issn=0966-0461|pmid=9661353}}</ref> From the mid-1900s to early 2000s, 15 new terms had emerged and were also being used to describe [[infection control]]. The variety of terms that described infection care led to a misunderstanding of practice recommendations and eventual low adherence to isolation precautions; this eventually forced the CDC to combine all 15 terms into one term called [[Isolation (health care)|isolation]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Landers|first=Timothy|last2=McWalters|first2=Jessica|last3=Behta|first3=Maryam|last4=Bufe|first4=Gina|last5=Ross|first5=Barbara|last6=Vawdrey|first6=David K.|last7=Larson|first7=Elaine|date=October 2010|title=Terms used for isolation practices by nurses at an academic medical center|journal=Journal of advanced nursing|volume=66|issue=10|pages=2309–2319|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2648.2010.05398.x|issn=0309-2402|pmc=2974777|pmid=20722801}}</ref> Nowadays barrier nursing is becoming a less commonly used term and is not even recognized by most reputable databases or online scientific journals. Yet when it is seldom used, it relates mostly to circumstantial protocols for situations regarding [[Isolation (health care)|isolation health care]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780443101472500382|title=Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation in Clinical Practice|last=Riley|first=Unell|date=2009|publisher=Churchill Livingstone|isbn=9780443101472|editor-last=Treleaven|editor-first=Jennifer|location=Edinburgh|pages=355–361|editor-last2=Barrett|editor-first2=A John}}</ref><ref name=":22">{{Cite book|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780702039355000689|title=Tropical Infectious Diseases: Principles, Pathogens and Practice (Third Edition)|last=Enría|first=Delia A.|last2=Mills|first2=James N.|last3=Bausch|first3=Dan|last4=Shieh|first4=Wun-Ju|last5=Peters|first5=C. J.|date=2011|publisher=W.B. Saunders|isbn=9780702039355|editor-last=Guerrant|editor-first=Richard L.|location=Edinburgh|pages=449–461|editor-last2=Walker|editor-first2=David H.|editor-last3=Weller|editor-first3=Peter F.}}</ref> The lack of constant use of the term is why there are no systematically reviewed articles on the topic and also why most of the sources that include the topic are from the late 1900s.
== Simple vs strict barrier nursing ==
=== Simple barrier nursing === Simple barrier nursing is used when an infectious agent is suspected within a patient and [[Universal precautions|standard precautions]] aren't working. Simple barrier nursing consists of utilizing sterile: gloves, masks, gowns, head-covers and eye protection.<ref name=":12"/><ref name="Mahmoud 375–381">{{Cite journal|last=Mahmoud|first=H. K.|last2=Schaefer|first2=U. W.|last3=Schüning|first3=F.|last4=Schmidt|first4=C. G.|last5=Bamberg|first5=M.|last6=Haralambie|first6=E.|last7=Linzenmeier|first7=G.|last8=Hantschke|first8=D.|last9=Grosse-Wilde|first9=H.|date=1984-11-01|title=Laminar air flow versus barrier nursing in marrow transplant recipients|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00319885|journal=Blut|language=en|volume=49|issue=5|pages=375–381|doi=10.1007/BF00319885|issn=0006-5242}}</ref> Nurses also wear Personalized protective equipment(PPE) to protect their bodies from infectious agents. Simple barrier nursing is often used for marrow transplants, [[Lassa virus|human Lassa virus]] transmission, [[viral hemorrhagic fever]] and other [[Virulence|virulent]] diseases.<ref name="Mahmoud 375–381"/><ref name=":22"/>
=== Strict Barrier Nursing === Strict barrier nursing, which is also known as "rigid barrier nursing", is used for the rarer and more specific deadly viruses and infections: [[smallpox]], [[Ebola virus disease|Ebola]] and [[rabies]]. Strict barrier nursing is a lot more demanding in terms of safety measure requirements because of the catastrophic effects that can occur if the disease or virus is allowed through the barrier. If patients cannot be isolated from one another completely, they have to at least be isolated from the rest of the patients within the hospital. In strict barrier nursing the patients and staff are usually isolated from the common population, and every attempt is made to establish a barrier between the inside and outside of the ward. The staff going on duty have to remove all outer clothing, pass through an [[airlock]] and put on a new set of PPE. When a staff member is going off duty, they are required to take a thorough shower and leave everything that was taken into the room to be disinfected or destroyed. While strict barrier nursing methods cannot always be enforced, especially in lower income areas and countries, any modifications made must be based on sound principles. Since infection can be spread through [[fomite]]s, clothes or oxygen, all efforts must be made to limit the spread of these vessels. The doctor's or nurse's hands must be thoroughly washed after touching anything in the cubicle. Taps and door-handles should be elbow- or foot-operated. Hands should be washed in the cubicle and dried outside to eliminate contamination from paper or cloth towels. In addition, [[antiseptic]] hand-cream, dispensed from a foot-operated wall container would also serve as an additional precaution.<ref name=":02"/><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780124169753000091|title=Emerging Infectious Diseases|last=Formenty|first=Pierre|date=2014|publisher=Academic Press|isbn=9780124169753|location=Amsterdam|pages=121–134}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/B9780702051012000182|title=Manson's Tropical Infectious Diseases (Twenty-Third Edition)|last=Warrell|first=Mary J.|date=2014|publisher=W.B. Saunders|isbn=9780702051012|editor-last=Farrar|editor-first=Jeremy|location=London|pages=195–206.e2|editor-last2=Hotez|editor-first2=Peter J.|editor-last3=Junghanss|editor-first3=Thomas|editor-last4=Kang|editor-first4=Gagandeep|editor-last5=Lalloo|editor-first5=David|editor-last6=White|editor-first6=Nicholas J.}}</ref>
== Psychiatric effects of barrier nursing ==
=== Positive effects === * Older patients and patients with more experience are content with their situation and approach it with more positivity.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|vauthors = Barratt R, Shaban R, Moyle W|year = 2010|title = Behind barriers: patients’ perceptions of source isolation for Methicillin‑resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)|url=https://research-repository.griffith.edu.au/handle/10072/35631|journal=Australian Journal of Advanced Nursing|volume=28|issue = 2|via=http://www.ajan.com.au/ajan_28.2.html}}</ref> * Some patients enjoy the experience of privacy and quietness that a single barrier room provided.
=== Negative effects === * Barrier nursing/isolation influences the quality of care and opportunity for emotional support of the patient.<ref name=":3" /> * Barrier nursing imposes barriers on the expression of a patient's own identity and any normal interpersonal relationships that he/she may have.<ref name=":3" /> * Barrier nursing can lead to anxiety, anger, frustration and fear especially if the patient isn't given enough information, or incorrect information on their disease.<ref name=":3" /> * Barrier nursing equipment can sometimes aggravate the social stigma associated with their infectious disease. ''Although participants understood the importance for Personalized Protective equipment, they still found that its use increased their fear and sense of stigma.'' <ref name=":3" /> * Placing patients in barrier nursing rooms may expose them to less medical care or access to associated treatment. ''Many researchers have indicated that healthcare professionals may regard a patient in source isolation differently from others. In studies regarding barrier nursing of patients with [[Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus]] , medical staff admitted to spending less time with patients in source isolation.<ref name=":3" />''
=== Solutions to negative effects of barrier nursing/isolation === * Empowering patients with accurate and meaningful information about their disease as a means of coping with their experience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unboundmedicine.com/medline/citation/6552913/'Patient_perspective'__psychological_effects_of_barrier_nursing_isolation_|title=PRIME PubMed {{!}} 'Patient perspective'--psychological effects of barrier nursing isolatio|website=www.unboundmedicine.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref> * Providing accurate information for family and visitors in order to ensure or reduce their initial ill‑informed fear of becoming infected.<ref name=":3" /> * Ensuring patients have access to a telephone as a means of communication with the outside world.<ref name=":3" /> * Designing facilities with windows and free space that allow patients to see the outside world and mitigate their feelings of confinement.<ref name=":3" />
== References== <references />
[[Category:Nursing]] [[Category:Infectious diseases]]

The '''burpee''', or '''squat thrust'''{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}, is a full body exercise used in [[strength training]] and as an [[aerobic exercise]]. The basic movement is performed in four steps and known as a "four-count burpee":<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20130104/new-york-city/real-story-behind-exercise-you-love-hate-burpee |title=The Real Story Behind the Exercise You Love to Hate: the Burpee |publisher=''DNA Info'' |author=Sheryl Dluginski |date=January 4, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818135031/https://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20130104/new-york-city/real-story-behind-exercise-you-love-hate-burpee |archivedate=August 18, 2017 |df= }}</ref><!-- NOTE: These standards are from the sources that state the origin of the original Burpee. All other varieties, including those popular in CrossFit and similar programs with further ranges of motion, are listed below.--> # Begin in a standing position. # Move into a [[Squat (exercise)|squat]] position with your hands on the ground. (count 1) # Kick your feet back into a plank position, while keeping your arms extended. (count 2) # Immediately return your feet into squat position. (count 3) # Stand up from the squat position (count 4) [[File:Burpee.webm|thumb|300x300px|Burpee demonstration]]
==Origin== The exercise was named in the 1930s for American [[physiologist]] Royal H. Burpee, who developed the ''burpee test''. He earned a Ph.D. in [[applied physiology]] from [[Teachers College, Columbia University]] in 1940 and created the "burpee" exercise as part of his Ph.D. thesis as a quick and simple way to assess fitness.<ref name="Columbia">{{cite web |url=https://pk.tc.columbia.edu/item/Seven-Quickly-Administered-Tests-Of-Physical-Capacity-And-Their-Use-In-Detecting-Physical-Incapacity-For-Motor-Activity-In-Men-And-Boys-51865 |title=Reference extract from Teachers College, Columbia University archive |work= |publisher=Teachers College, Columbia University |accessdate=8 November 2011}}</ref> The exercise was popularized when the United States Armed Services adopted it as a way to assess the fitness level of recruits when the US entered [[World War II]]. Consisting of a series of the exercises performed in rapid succession, the test was meant to be a quick measure of agility, coordination, and strength.<ref name="OED">{{cite web |url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/burpee |title=Definition of burpee from Oxford Dictionaries Online |work= |publisher=Oxford University Press |accessdate=24 May 2010}}</ref>
== Progression == {{Refimprove section|date=July 2018}} The way to perform a burpee as originally intended has progressed since the 1930s. The up phase of the burpee used to be with the feet landing between the hands while still grounded, which creates unnecessary pressure on the lower back. It's now more common to land the feet on the outside of the hands.
== Confusion == {{Refimprove section|date=July 2018}} The burpee is sometimes confused with a [[Sprawl (grappling)|sprawl]]. A sprawl is similar to the burpee with the main difference being that the hips are thrust towards the ground in the plank position.
== Variants == {{Refimprove section|date=March 2014}} ; Box-jump burpee : The athlete jumps onto a box, rather than straight up and down.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.crossfitendurance.com/blog/3/post/41 | title=Demonstrations: Box-Jump Burpee | publisher=Crossfit Endurance | accessdate=9 July 2014}}</ref> ; Burpee broad jump: A burpee followed by a stationary two footed distance jump.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fitnasty.com/?p=180 |title=Movement of the Week: the burpee broad jump |accessdate=9 July 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714185719/http://www.fitnasty.com/?p=180 |archivedate=July 14, 2014 }}</ref> ; Burpee push up (also known as a "bastardo"): The athlete performs one push-up after assuming the [[Plank (exercise)|extended plank]] position.<ref name="dare_BurpPU">{{Cite web| title = Burpees - with Push-Up | website= darebee.com | access-date = February 10, 2018| url = https://darebee.com/exercises/burpees-with-push-up.html}}</ref> ; CrossFit burpee: The athlete performs a standard four count burpee with the addition of a tricep push up at the bottom, where the chest and thighs touch the floor, and jump at the top of the standing position with hands above the head.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://greatist.com/fitness/how-to-do-the-perfect-burpee |title=How to Do the Perfect Burpee |publisher=greatist.com |date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> ; CrossFit speed burpee : The athlete drops to the ground with the chest and thighs touching the floor, creating a hollow back through hip extension, rolling onto the knees getting up, and perform a jump with hands above the head. This version is all about efficiency, high reps. ; Dumbbell burpee: The athlete holds a pair of [[dumbbell]]s while performing the exercise.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L_QjiZGhZcM | title=Reebok CrossFit ONE Movement Demo "Dumbbell Burpee" | publisher=Reebok Crossfit One | date=Feb 22, 2013 | accessdate=9 July 2014}}</ref> ; Eight-count push up<ref name="PopularScience">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oiUDAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA203&ots=q3LvcPF_ry&pg=PA58#v=twopage&q&f=false |title=Can we make our soldiers tough enough? from Popular Science, 1944 |accessdate=12 October 2012}}</ref> or Double burpee: The athlete performs two push-ups after assuming the plank position. This cancels the drive from landing after the jump and makes the next jump harder. Each part of the burpee might be repeated to make it even harder. ; Hindu push up burpee: Instead of a regular push up, do a [[Push-up#Hindu push-up|Hindu push up]]. ; Jump-over burpee : The athlete jumps over an obstacle between burpees. ; Jump up burpee : The athlete jumps straight up as high as possible at the end of the movement, before beginning the next burpee.<ref name="dare_BurpJ">{{Cite web| title = Burpees| website= darebee.com| access-date = February 10, 2018 | url = https://darebee.com/exercises/burpees-exercise.html}} - includes jump and push up variations</ref> ; Knee push-up burpee : The athlete bends their knees and rests them on the ground before performing the push up. ; Long-jump burpee : The athlete jumps forward, not upward. ; Muscle-up burpee : Combine a muscle-up (a variation of a [[pull-up (exercise)|pull-up]]) with the jump or do a muscle-up instead of the jump. ; One-armed burpee : The athlete uses only one arm for the whole exercise including the [[pushup]]. ; One leg burpee : The athlete stands on one leg, bends at the waist and puts hands on ground so they are aligned with shoulders. Next jump back with the standing leg to plank position. Jump forward with the one leg that was extended, and do a one-leg jump. Repeat on opposite side.<ref>http://strength.stack52.com/periodic-table-of-bodyweight-exercises/</ref> ; Parkour burpee : Following one burpee on the ground, the athlete jumps upon a table and performs the second burpee on the table, then jumps back to the initial position. ; Pull-up burpee : Combine a pull-up with the jump or do a pull-up instead of the jump. ; Side burpee : The athlete bends at waist and places hand shoulder-width apart to the side of right or left foot. Jump both legs out to side and land on the outer and inner sides of your feet. Jump back in, jump up, and repeat on opposite side. ; Squat Thrust : Same as a four-count burpee. ; Tuck-jump burpee : The athlete pulls their knees to their chest (tucks) at the peak of the jump.
== World records == At 4 pm on May 17, 2014, in Greenwood, SC, Cameron Dorn broke two burpee world records: the most burpees performed in 12 hours with 5,657 and the most burpees completed in 24 hours with 10,105.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://greenwoodcalendar.com/the-making-of-cameron-dorns-burpee-world-record/ |title=The Making of Cameron Dorn’s Burpee World Record |publisher=Greenwood Calendar |accessdate=10 July 2014}}</ref>
At 6 am on October 21, 2013, in Portland, OR, Lloyd Weema broke the burpee world record: the most chest to ground burpees performed in 72 hours with 9,480.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uniqueworldrecords.com/find-out-more---marathon-attempts/2014ma408-most-chest-to-ground-burpees-in-72-hours |title=Lloyd Weema's 72 Hour Burpee World Record |publisher=Unique World Records |accessdate=9 July 2015}}</ref>
On July 23, 2018, in Hobart, Tasmania, Charlie Gard achieved a record 851 burpees in one hour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-07-23/burpee-man-charlie-gard-smashes-record/10024618|title=Tasmania's burpee man Charlie Gard smashes Guinness World Record|accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
