{{Infobox officeholder | name = Siniša Varga | honorific-suffix = | image = Siniša Varga.jpg | imagesize = | office = [[Ministry of Health (Croatia)|Minister of Health]] | term_start = 11 June 2014 | term_end = 22 January 2016 | primeminister= [[Zoran Milanović]] | predecessor = [[Rajko Ostojić]] | successor = [[Dario Nakić]] | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1965|09|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Zagreb]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]] (now:[[Croatia]]) | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia]] | alma_mater = [[University of Zagreb]]
([[School of Dental Medicine, University of Zagreb|School of Dental Medicine]]) | occupation = [[Dentist]] | spouse = | children = 2 | website = | footnotes = }} '''Siniša Varga''' (born August 24, 1965) is a Croatian dentist and politician who served as [[Ministry of Health (Croatia)|Minister of Health]] in the centre-left [[Cabinet of Zoran Milanović]] from 2014 until 2016. ==Early life == Varga was born on August 24, 1965 in [[Zagreb]]. He graduated in 1990 at the Faculty of Dentistry, [[University of Zagreb]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hzzo.hr/sinisa-varga/ |title=Hrvatski zavod za zdravstveno osiguranje » Siniša Varga |publisher=Hzzo.hr |date= |accessdate=2016-08-07}} ==Dentist == From 1993 to 1997 he specialized in [[prosthodontics]] at the Dental Clinic of the [[Clinical Hospital Centre Zagreb]]. As part of his specialized practice in 1995 he worked in Gothenburg (Sweden) at Branemark Implantology Clinic. In 1997, as a specialist in dental prosthetics, he was head of the surgical prosthetics, Clinical Department of Oral Surgery, for surgery of the face and jaw, at University Hospital Dubrava. The center is the only one of its kind in Croatia. His special interest in general and health management earned him a degree of international quality systems manager for the International Standard [[ISO 9001]]: 2000 from the European Organization for Quality. From 2000 to 2002, he worked as a consultant for the [[World Bank]] project on [[health care reform]] in the Republic of Croatia. During this period he was an assistant director of the Clinical Hospital Dubrava. In 2004, Varga became responsible for the organization of the teaching module "Resource Management in Health Care", study "Leadership and Management of Health and Science" at the School of Public Health "Andrija Štampar" at University of Zagreb.{{cite web|url=http://vijesti.hrt.hr/247290/biografije-novih-ministara-sinise-varge-i-vedrana-mornara |title=HRT: Biografije novih ministara Siniše Varge i Vedrana Mornara |language=hr |publisher=Vijesti.hrt.hr |date= |accessdate=2016-08-07}} In 2008 he became a consultant on a World Bank project to reform health care in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]].{{cite web|author=Tečajna lista |url=http://www.poslovni.hr/hrvatska/procitajte-zivotopis-sinise-varge-273508 |title=Pročitajte životopis Siniše Varge - Poslovni dnevnik |publisher=Poslovni.hr |date= |accessdate=2016-08-07}} He is a member of the Croatian Dental Society, [[Croatian Medical Association]], where he served as the Secretary-General for two four-year terms. He is a member of the Croatian Society of Volunteers of Croatian Homeland war for independence, the Croatian Society of Quality Managers and the Croatian Standards Institute in two technical committees: dentistry and quality management. Varga is a court expert for prosthodontics and a mentor for education of new experts.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} ==Political career== From 2002 to 2004 he was an official of the Croatian Government in the [[Ministry of Health (Croatia)|Ministry of Health and Social Welfare]], as the deputy minister of health for professional medical affairs. The government appointed Varga to a working group for preparation of negotiations for [[European Union accession]] in 2007. In 2010 Siniša Varga became a member of the [[Social Democratic Party of Croatia|Croatian Social Democratic Party]]. After directing the Croatian Institute for Health Insurance from April 2012 to June 2014, the government appointed him as Minister of Health.{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/06/11/us-croatia-government-idUSKBN0EM10420140611 |title=Croatia PM replaces health, education ministers in mini-reshuffle |publisher=Reuters |date=June 11, 2014 |accessdate=October 12, 2015}} ==Private life== Varga is married and has two children. He was a volunteer in [[Croatian War of Independence]] and holds a memorial of Homeland war. He speaks English and some French. He is an active member of the Rotary Club of Zagreb through which he supports humanitarian actions. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web |url=https://vlada.gov.hr/about-the-government/members-of-the-government/government-members/sinisa-varga-15059/15059 |title=Government of the Republic of Croatia - Siniša Varga |publisher=Government of Croatia |accessdate=October 12, 2015}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Varka, Sinisa}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Croatian dentists]] [[Category:Health ministers of Croatia]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Zagreb]] [[Category:Social Democratic Party of Croatia politicians]] [[Category:University of Zagreb alumni]] [[Category:Representatives in the modern Croatian Parliament]]

[[Image:SlowFoodNation sf.jpg|right|250px]] '''Slow Food Nation''' was an event organized by [[Slow Food USA]], which celebrates [[slow food|slow]] and [[sustainable agriculture|sustainable]] foods. Slow Food Nation attracted an estimated audience of more than 50,000 people.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/23/dining/23slow.html?_r=1&ei=5087&em=&en=5101c243fd80d293&ex=1216958400&pagewanted=all&oref=slogin|title=Slow Food Savors Its Big Moment |last=Severson|first=Kim|date=July 23, 2008|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2008-08-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/08/29/BACF12LHMU.DTL|title=Crowds look, learn and taste as Slow Food Nation opens|date=August 30, 2008 |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|accessdate=2008-08-30}}</ref> Held over the [[Labor Day]] weekend from August 29 to September 1, 2008, the majority of the event took place in either [[San Francisco]]'s [[Civic Center, San Francisco, California|Civic Center]] and [[Fort Mason Center]]. Slow Food Nation's founder is influential [[chef]] and author [[Alice Waters]]. In addition to a specially-created "[[victory garden]]" in front of [[San Francisco City Hall]], a marketplace, tastings, photo exhibits [http://gayeton.com/gayeton_photowork.html], and other events, Slow Food Nation featured panels led by food luminaries such as [[Michael Pollan]] and [[Eric Schlosser]], as well as the founder of Slow Food, [[Carlo Petrini]].<ref name="post">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/08/29/AR2008082903447.html|title=As Food Becomes a Cause, Meeting Puts Issues on the Table|last=Black|first=Jane|date=August 30, 2008|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=2008-08-30}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:SlowFoodVictoryGarden.jpg|Civic Center Victory Garden in front of City Hall Image:Victory gardens at slow food nation.jpg|A close-up of the Victory Garden Image:Slow food nation, civic center.jpg|the Marketplace Image:Slow Food Nation Marketplace.jpg|the Marketplace, with art featuring the event's slogan "Come to the Table" </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commonscat}} * [http://slowfoodusa.org/slow-food-nations Slow Food Nations], official site * [https://www.youtube.com/user/SlowFoodNation Slow Food Nation], [[YouTube]] channel * [https://www.flickr.com/groups/820293@N25/ photo pool] on [[Flickr]]
[[Category:Slow Food]] [[Category:Food politics]] [[Category:Culture of San Francisco]] [[Category:American cuisine]] [[Category:Food and drink in the San Francisco Bay Area]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.5)
revision.text:
A '''smokeasy''' (also spelled '''smoke-easy''' or '''smokeeasy''') is a business, especially a bar or drinking venue, which allows smoking despite a [[smoking ban]] enacted as a [[criminal law]] or an [[occupational safety and health]] regulation. The term is also used to describe locations and events promoted by tobacco companies to avoid or evade bans on smoking.<ref name="urlPeter Stuyvesant’s Adelaide Smokeasy | The Enthusiast">{{cite web|url=http://www.theenthusiast.com.au/archives/2009/peter-stuyvesants-adelaide-smokeasy/|title=Peter Stuyvesant’s Adelaide Smokeasy | The Enthusiast|format=|work=|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100506084848/http://www.theenthusiast.com.au/archives/2009/peter-stuyvesants-adelaide-smokeasy/|archivedate=2010-05-06|df=}}</ref> The word was added to the ''[[New Oxford American Dictionary]]'' in 2005,<ref>"New Words," ''Chicago Tribune'', June 5, 2005.</ref> although it was used as early as 1978.<ref>Melinda Beck, "No Smoking," ''Newsweek'', October 2, 1978</ref><ref>[http://www.wordspy.com/words/smoke-easy.asp Wordspy: Smoke-easy]</ref> It is a [[portmanteau]] of ''[[smoking]]'' and ''[[speakeasy]]''.
==Background== Smoking bans have been pejoratively described as a type of [[sumptuary law]], a law that attempts to regulate habits of consumption, like the [[prohibition of alcohol]] and [[prohibition (drugs)|drug prohibition]].<ref>''Johns-Manville Sales Corp. v. International Ass'n of Machinists, Local Lodge 1609'', 621 F.2d 756, 760 ([[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit|5th Cir.]] 1980)</ref><ref>''People v. King'', 102 A.D.2d 710, 712 ([[New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division|N.Y. App. Div. 1st. Dept.]] 1984) (Carro, J., dissenting)</ref><ref>John C. Fox, "An assessment of the current legal climate concerning smoking in the workplace," 13 St. Louis U. Pub. L. Rev. 591, 623-624 (1994)</ref><ref>[[William de Wiveleslie Abney]], ''Colour Vision'', p. 140 (Wood: 1895)</ref><ref>[[Wilhelm Georg Friedrich Roscher]], ''Principles of Political Economy'', p. 248 (New York, Holt: 1878)</ref><ref>Herman F. Selvin, ''The University of California and California Law and Lawyers, 1920-1978'', transcript of interview by Anne Brower, p. 35 (1976 and 1978)</ref><ref>"Summary," ''The American Architect'', Vol. XCII, No. 1650, p. 2 (Aug. 10, 1907)</ref><ref>[[Harvey W. Wiley]], in H.S. Gray, "The Boy and the Cigarette Habit," ''Education'', Vol. XXX, No. 5, p. 298 (Jan. 1909)</ref><ref>[[Lewis H. Lapham|Lewis Lapham]], "Notebook: Social hygiene" ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', July 1, 2003</ref><ref>[[Barbara Amiel]], "Good luck if you've got nasty underclass tastes," ''[[Maclean's]]'', September 10, 2007</ref><ref>[[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]], ''[[Bobos in Paradise|Bobos in Paradise: The New Upper Class and How They Got There]]'' (Simon & Schuster: 2000)</ref> Such prohibitions tend to trigger [[underground economy|underground economies]].<ref name="bykofsky">[[Stu Bykofsky]], "'Smoke-easys' ignore the tobacco ban", ''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', March 27, 2007</ref><ref name="devilspicnic">Taras Grescoe, ''The Devil's Picnic: Around the World in Search of Forbidden Fruit'' (Bloomsbury USA: 2005)</ref><ref name="seattlesmokers">[http://www.seattlepi.com/local/272211_smokeeasy31.html "Smokers find refuge in secret nicotine dens"], ''Seattlepi.com'', May 31, 2006</ref><ref name="ashtoria">"Cig-ban Scofflaws light up Ash-Toria," ''The [[New York Post]]'', May 8, 2006.</ref> For, when a sector of the population is prohibited by law from consuming a certain good, or consuming a certain good in a certain way, inevitably, some will flout that prohibition and provide the good or the means of consuming the good in a black-market fashion.<ref name="devilspicnic"/><ref name="ashtoria"/> Thus, just as [[prohibition in the United States]] led to the [[speakeasy]] (an establishment in which alcohol was sold in contravention of the law), so too have smoking bans led to the smokeasy.<ref name="bykofsky"/><ref name="devilspicnic"/><ref name="seattlesmokers"/><ref name="ashtoria"/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bolinger|first1=Patricia|title=Smokeeasy Crackdown Gets Serious|url=http://www.ecig-reviews.equinoxbeestudio.com|publisher=Denise J. Logan|accessdate=24 August 2009}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Operations== Some smokeasy operators simply operate openly, calculating that the fines they will pay are merely a cost of doing business. Others employ stealth tactics; for example, in [[Philadelphia]], where it is illegal to have an [[ashtray]] in the workplace, smokeasy [[bartender]]s sometimes will use cups filled with some water to serve as ashtrays.<ref name="bykofsky"/> A visit from the city inspector then merely requires getting customers to extinguish their smoking materials and disposing of the [[cigarette]] butts.<ref name="seattlesmokers"/>
Because smokeasies are breaking the law, usually locations are spread by word-of-mouth; they even may involve the swearing of secrecy.<ref name="seattlesmokers"/> Although some smokeasies are [[underground restaurant|underground establishments]],<ref name="scotsman">[http://news.scotsman.com/scotland.cfm?id=1271792006 "Warning over 'smoke-easy' lock-ins"], ''[[The Scotsman]]'', August 29, 2006</ref> others are ordinary bars that covertly permit smoking in the evening.<ref name="seattlesmokers"/>
Sometimes businesses choose to openly defy existing smoking bans due to loss of business. There are cases in which establishments risk closure and heavy fines to draw attention to the issue, which includes being documented in the press as a smokeasy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.khon2.com/home/ticker/5425396.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725165328/http://www.khon2.com/home/ticker/5425396.html |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }}</ref>
==Tobacco companies and smokeasies==
Tobacco companies have used a variety of tactics to encourage the sale and consumption of cigarettes in the presence of smoking bans, and the term smokeasy has commonly been used to describe events and establishments of this kind. [[Imperial Tobacco]] hires public venues to promote its Peter Stuyvesant brand.<ref name="urlPeter Stuyvesant’s Adelaide Smokeasy | The Enthusiast"/><ref name="urlAdelaideNow... Secret smokes party for VIPs">{{cite news |url=http://www.news.com.au/adelaidenow/story/0,22606,25290946-2682,00.html |title=AdelaideNow... Secret smokes party for VIPs |work= Sunday Mail (SA)|accessdate= | first=Petra | last=Starke | date=April 5, 2009}}</ref> In Chicago, [[RJ Reynolds]] established an "upscale smoking lounge" serving alcohol and food, but classified as a retail tobacco store.<ref name="urlChicagos (Legal) Smokeasy - Hit & Run : Reason Magazine">{{cite web |url=http://reason.com/blog/2006/01/19/chicagos-legal-smokeasy |title=Chicago's (Legal) Smokeasy - Hit & Run : Reason Magazine |format= |work= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Examples==
===New York City=== Within one month of the passage of [[New York City]]'s smoking ban in 2003, smokeasies were quickly predicted.<ref name="vanharken">[http://www.vanharken.com/smokingban/profile/profile-28days.html Smoking Ban NYC Profile - 28 days].</ref> Shortly thereafter, some bartenders began to hear word of smokeasies and theorized that some former regulars who were smokers had switched to the smokeasies.<ref>[http://www.thevillager.com/villager_9/sidewalksoakings.html "Sidewalk Soakings,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927210212/http://www.thevillager.com/villager_9/sidewalksoakings.html |date=2007-09-27 }} ''The Villager'', June 25, 2003.</ref> Today, both covert and overt smokeasies exist throughout New York City and the whole state of [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>"Cig ban? What cig ban? City hot spots smoking again," ''The New York Post'', May 27, 2007</ref><ref>[http://funkypundit.blogspot.com/2007/04/empire-state-smokeasies.html Empire State Smokeasies], ''Funkypundit Blog'', April 2, 2007</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/04/nyregion/04SMOK.html?ex=1388552400&en=00adcfb68b653f75&ei=5007&partner=USERLAND "Waiting to inhale"], ''The New York Times'', January 4, 2004</ref><ref>"Lighting-up time: Big Apple meets Big Smoke," ''[[The Times]]'', April 1, 2005.</ref><ref>"Gangsters will be the real winners in smoking ban," ''Scottish [[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'', January 7, 2005.</ref><ref>"Smoked out?" ''The Buffalo News'', February 18, 2004.</ref><ref>"N.Y. restaurants cutting trans fat from menus," ''The [[Washington Times]]'', December 6, 2006.</ref><ref>"The Guide to the Guides," ''[[The Observer]]'' ([[United Kingdom]]), January 30, 2005.</ref><ref>"A year after New York smoking ban, debate still rages over effects," ''The [[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', March 31, 2004.</ref><ref>"Late Night Cracks in City's Ban," ''[[New York Post]]'', March 4, 2004.</ref><ref>"On The Run," ''The [[New York Times]]'', June 8, 2003.</ref><ref>"Even for V.I.P.'s, Sometimes A Cigar Is Just Illegal," ''The New York Times'', August 14, 2004</ref> As a result, New York City unexpectedly had to begin a campaign of enforcing its smoking ban: in 2005–2006, the city issued 601 citations to smokeasies, including 232 in [[Queens]], 158 in [[Manhattan]], 126 in [[Brooklyn]], 73 in [[The Bronx]] and 12 in [[Staten Island]].<ref name="ashtoria"/>
===Hawaii=== In [[Hawaii]], a large number of establishments openly defy the statewide smoking ban, one of America's strictest, which went into effect on November 16, 2006.<ref name="honoluluweekly">Dean Carrico, "Thank you for [not] smoking: Bartenders and bar owners continue to ignore smoking ban," ''[[Honolulu Weekly]]'', June 27, 2007</ref><ref>Mark Niesse, "Smoking ban openly defied by some bars," ''[[The Honolulu Advertiser]]'', February 18, 2007</ref><ref>Laurie Au, "Smoking-ban rules, enforcement coming: Bar owners OK with patrons defying smoking ban," ''The [[Honolulu Star-Bulletin]]'', June 30, 2007</ref> Several bars have disclosed their defiance in local newspapers and have invited television stations to film the unlawful smoking.<ref name="hawaiibans">[http://pacific.bizjournals.com/pacific/stories/2007/02/19/story2.html?b=1171861200%5E1419319 "What smoking ban? Some bars defy new law,"] ''Pacific Business Journal'', February 16, 2007</ref> As of 2010, no bar has been fined, and open defiance continues.<ref name="hawaiibans"/> Up to half of the bar owners in [[Honolulu]] have signed statements claiming losses averaging 30% and expressed open concern at the anti-smoking lobby claim that it would not affect business, a claim that was later reinforced by the Hawaii Department of Health's air quality study and Honolulu Liquor Commission sales data.<ref name="honoluluweekly"/> As a result, proposals currently are before the [[Hawaii Legislature]] to exempt bars from the statewide smoking ban by creating a new type of liquor license which permits the licensee to allow smoking.<ref>Mark Niesse, "Bill would allow smoking in bars: Some establishments ignore the ban and are going unpunished," ''The Honolulu Star-Bulletin'', February 21, 2007</ref>
===The Netherlands=== With the passing of a 2008 smoking ban, many Dutch cafes had become smokeasies despite facing fines up to 18,500 [[Euros]]. The Dutch pub owners viewed their defiance as necessary to stay in business, with the group [[Save the Small Cafe Owners]] stating the ban has cost them 1/3 of their business. The same groups also organized a 1500-5000 owner strong public protest of the ban in November, 2008.<ref>[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5ibVE6grha5qJ3su-g3vkNyxnWHAg]</ref>
After two years of continued opposition by bar and cafe owners, in the fall of 2010 the Dutch government repealed the ban for smaller bars and cafes which had complained loudly about loss of business.<ref>MSNBC http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39992553/ns/world_news-europe/</ref>
===Elsewhere=== Smokeasies have become a noted phenomenon in most jurisdictions with a ban on smoking in bars and/or restaurants, including [[Alberta]],<ref>Collette Derworiz, "City to enforce smoking ban: Bylaw officers will charge bar owners flouting rules," ''The [[Calgary Herald]]'', January 11, 2007</ref> [[Arizona]],<ref>"Tempe wants to wipe out its 'smoke-easies,' ''The [[Arizona Republic]]'', August 8, 2002</ref> [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]],<ref>"Where there's smoke," ''Boston Magazine'', May, 2005.</ref> [[California]],<ref>[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?sec=travel&res=9C00EFD61331F932A05751C1A961958260 "California's Ban to Clear Smoke Inside Most Bars"] ''The [[New York Times]]'', December 31, 1997</ref><ref>[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/1998/05/15/MN80568.DTL "The Land of Smoke-Easies, $500 Barfs"]. ''The San Francisco Chronicle', May 15, 1998</ref><ref>"Suck It Up," ''SF Weekly'', January 22, 2003</ref> [[Colorado]],<ref>[http://gazette.com/bars-rebel-against-smoking-ban/article/19674 "Bars rebel against smoking ban,"] ''The [[Colorado Springs Gazette]]'', March 28, 2007</ref> [[Columbia, Missouri]],<ref>"Tickets add heat to ban on smoking," ''Columbia Tribune'', March 3, 2007</ref> [[Delaware]],<ref>"Smoking bans burn businesses," ''Delaware News Journal'', December 15, 2002</ref> [[Dublin]],<ref name="scotsman"/><ref>"Beware of complacency as 'smoke-easies' appear", ''The [[Irish News]]'', June 12, 2007</ref> [[Germany]],<ref>[http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0,,2243763,00.html "'Nazi' claim as Germans rebel over smoking ban"] ''The Observer'', January 20, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,527908,00.html "German Don Quixotes Tilt against Smoking Ban"], ''Der Spiegel'', January 11, 2008</ref> [[Illinois]],<ref>[http://www.wrex.com/News/index.php?ID=28935 "Three South Beloit Bars Fined for Smoking Ban Violation"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517174906/http://www.wrex.com/News/index.php?ID=28935 |date=2008-05-17 }}, ''WREX-TV'', May 20, 2008</ref><ref>Eric Petersen, "Three Schaumburg businesses violate new smoking ban," ''The [[Daily Herald (Arlington Heights)|Arlington Heights Daily Herald]]'', March, 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.thetelegraph.com/articles/ban_11408___article.html/smoking_bar.html "Smoking ban holds up, despite opposition"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081224215115/http://www.thetelegraph.com/articles/ban_11408___article.html/smoking_bar.html |date=2008-12-24 }}, ''The Telegraph'', February 23, 2008</ref> [[Manitoba]],<ref>Michelle MacAfee, "Manitobans smoke it up," ''The [[Canadian Press]]'', October 31, 2004</ref><ref>David Schmeichel, "Smoke cops strike: Treherne hotelier vows to fight 'fascist law,'" ''The [[Winnipeg Sun]]'', November 13, 2004</ref> [[Minnesota]],<ref>G.R. Anderson, Jr., [http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2006/02/busted_the_rumor_and_truth_of.php "Busted: The rumor and truth of one club's struggle against the smoking ban,"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101013153345/http://blogs.citypages.com/blotter/2006/02/busted_the_rumor_and_truth_of.php |date=2010-10-13 }} ''[[City Pages]]'', February 17, 2006</ref> [[Ohio]],<ref>Tracy Wheeler, "Smoking ban leaves some bars smoldering," ''The [[Akron Beacon Journal]]'', November 18, 2007</ref><ref>Elaine T. Secora, "Smoke and fire," ''[[Cleveland Scene]]'', January 31, 2007</ref><ref>[http://yellowisthecolor.wordpress.com/2007/03/28/smoke-easies-altoid-tins-blue-moon-janis-joplin-and-vivid-imaginations/ "smoke-easies, altoid tins, blue moon, janis joplin and vivid imaginations"] ''Yellow Is The Color Blog''</ref><ref>[http://www.marionstar.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071227/NEWS01/712270318 "Smoking ban fines about to get bigger"], ''The Marion Star'', December 27, 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.cleveland.com/news/plaindealer/index.ssf?/base/cuyahoga/120203113016350.xml&coll=2 "Underground smokehouses open amid crackdown on smoking, strip clubs"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080311104021/http://www.cleveland.com/news/plaindealer/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fcuyahoga%2F120203113016350.xml&coll=2 |date=2008-03-11 }}, ''Cleveland Plain Dealer'', February 3, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.ohio.com/news/break_news/19096649.html "Columbus bar challenges enforcement of smoking ban"], ''Associated Press'', May 20, 2008</ref> [[Philadelphia]],<ref name="bykofsky"/><ref>"New vice, same solutions," ''Philadelphia Daily News'', March 26, 2007</ref><ref>[http://blogs.fortwayne.com/opening_arguments/2007/03/smokeeasies.html "Smoke-easies"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930200105/http://blogs.fortwayne.com/opening_arguments/2007/03/smokeeasies.html |date=2007-09-30 }}, ''[[Fort Wayne News-Sentinel]]'', March 28, 2007</ref><ref>Natalie Pompilio, "Ban hardly a crushing blow," ''The [[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', November, 2006</ref> [[Qatar]],<ref>[http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=192251&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 "Ban on smoking openly flouted"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607103719/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=192251&version=1&template_id=36&parent_id=16 |date=2011-06-07 }}, ''The Gulf Times'', December 27, 2007</ref> [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]],<ref name="seattlesmokers"/><ref>"Law or no law, Seattle bars still smoking," UPI, June 1, 2006</ref> [[South Carolina]],<ref>[http://www.beaufortgazette.com/local/story/434428.html "Snitches silent about county's 16-month-old smoking ban"]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''The Beaufort Gazette'', May 10, 2008</ref> [[Toronto]],<ref>[http://torontosun.com/News/Columnists/Warmington_Joe/2006/05/25/1596510.html "Speakeasies? Nah, smoke-easies"], ''The Toronto Sun'', May 25, 2006</ref> the [[United Kingdom]],<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-472889/Defiant-bar-owner-finds-loophole-flout-smoking-ban.html "Defiant bar owner finds 'loophole' to flout smoking ban"]. ''The Daily Mail'', August 3, 2007</ref><ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/200802070019 "My local smoke-easy,"] ''The New Statesman'', February 7, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.thepublican.com/story.asp?storyCode=58732 "The Big Smoke-easy,"] ''The Publican'', February 21, 2008</ref> [[Thailand]],<ref>[http://davetheravebangkok.com/2008/02/27/thailand-night-fever-9/ Thailand Night Fever]. Dave The Rave’s Thailand Go-Go Bars & Bargirls Guide</ref> [[Utah]],<ref>[http://www.utahstatesman.com/news/2006/12/06/Opinion/Column.Everyone.Head.For.The.smokeEasy-2524825.shtml "Everyone Head for the Smoke-Easy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080120010429/http://www.utahstatesman.com/news/2006/12/06/Opinion/Column.Everyone.Head.For.The.smokeEasy-2524825.shtml |date=2008-01-20 }}, ''Utah Statesman'', December 12, 2006</ref> and [[Washington, D.C.]]<ref>"Smoke-easies offer cover from puff police; Aficionados just want a place to light up, relax," ''The [[Washington Times]]'', November 20, 2003</ref>
==See also== * [[Smoking ban]] * [[List of smoking bans in the United States]] *[[Tobacco control]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{-}} {{Smoking nav}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=April 2008}} [[File:SJP-Logo-Blue.jpg|right|142x142px|St. John Providence]] '''St. John Providence''' is a non-profit corporation that owns and operates four [[hospital]]s and over 125 medical facilities in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Michigan]]. Its headquarters are in the St. John Providence Corporate Services Building in [[Warren, Michigan|Warren]] in [[Metro Detroit]].<ref>"[http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/ContactUs/ Contact Us]." St. John Providence. Retrieved on May 5, 2013. "Corporate Mailing Address St. John Providence Corporate Services Building 28000 Dequindre Warren, MI 48092"</ref> The parent company of St. John Providence is [[Ascension Health|Ascension]] in St. Louis. <ref name=StJohnmovesup2000>"[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DTNB&s_site=detnews&f_site=detnews&f_sitename=Detroit+News%2C+The+%28MI%29&p_multi=DTNB&p_theme=gannett&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F7501EFB600F6E2&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM St. John Health chief moves up]." ''[[The Detroit News]]''. May 26, 2000. Retrieved on May 19, 2013. Document ID det7915562.</ref>
The organization has more than 18,000 employees and operates 2,033 licensed beds.<ref>"St. John Providence Corporate Fact Sheet." St. John Providence. Web. http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/Newsroom/SJHInfo/Facts/Corporate/</ref>
==History==
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:SJHMCfromtheair.JPG|St. John Hospital and Medical Center aerial view|right|thumbnail]] --> The system started in 1999 with the merger of the Providence Health System and the St. John Health System into the St. John Health System due to the merger of the two systems' respective Roman Catholic congregation sponsors, the [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul|Daughters of Charity]] and the [[Sisters of St. Joseph]], into [[Ascension Health]].<ref name=Greenehospitals>Greene, Jay. "[http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20100308/FREE/100309857 New name for St. John Health System]." ''[[Crain's Detroit Business]]''. March 8, 2010. Retrieved on July 4, 2013.</ref> The St. John Hospital System, under Anthony R. Tersigni, grew from four to ten hospitals. In May 2000 he was appointed as the senior vice president of [[Ascension Health]]'s Great Lakes Division.<ref name=StJohnmovesup2000/>
By 2001, the Emergency Center staff was treating more than 76,400 patients as a major level-two emergency center for the east side community.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
In 2003 the hospital stated that it expected to have a $40 million loss for its 2004 fiscal year.<ref>"[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DTNB&s_site=detnews&f_site=detnews&f_sitename=Detroit+News%2C+The+%28MI%29&p_multi=DTNB&p_theme=gannett&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FA5B738A9BD9039&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM St. John CEO says system is ahead of curve]." ''[[The Detroit News]]''. April 11, 2003. Retrieved on October 20, 2013.</ref> In 2003 the system supported a proposed Michigan law that would allow the state health systems to move more hospital beds from Detroit to the suburbs.<ref>"[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DTNB&s_site=detnews&f_site=detnews&f_sitename=Detroit+News%2C+The+%28MI%29&p_multi=DTNB&p_theme=gannett&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FB63244E53FD35F&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Health system exec speaks on suburb moves]." ''[[The Detroit News]]''. May 30, 2003. Retrieved on October 20, 2013. "DETROIT -- A state commission heard public testimony this week about whether it should approve a law that would let Detroit's financially strapped health systems move hospital beds to the suburbs. Bob Asmussen, vice president of strategic planning for St. John Health System, was recently interviewed by The Detroit News on the issue. Here's an edited version of the discussion: Q. St. John Health supports the new law that would allow health systems to move up to a third of a "</ref>
In 2008 the system had 18,000 employees. On April 8 of that year Patricia A. Maryland, the system CEO, announced that as part of a $85 million cost cutting restructuring, the company planned to lay off 300 non-clinical workers with almost 50 management positions being cut. She also announced that the system would not fill 100 job vacancies, including 40 vacancies for management positions.<ref>Gosselin, Gary. "[http://www.mlive.com/business/index.ssf/2008/04/st_john_health_fires_then_hire.html St. John Health fires, then hires] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020222220/http://www.mlive.com/business/index.ssf/2008/04/st_john_health_fires_then_hire.html |date=2013-10-20 }}." [[Mlive]]. Thursday April 17, 2008. Retrieved on October 19, 2013.</ref>
In 2010 St. John Health System was renamed to the St. John Providence Health System. The organization officials stated that "Providence" was added to the name in order to reflect the system's "spiritually centered patient care experience".<ref name=Greenehospitals/>
===Predecessor systems=== In 1910 the Providence Hospital opened in [[Detroit]]. The Sisters of St. Joseph built St. John Hospital in 1952,<ref name=Greenehospitals/> with 250 beds and 70 employees on Moross Road at the old Beaupre farm in a section called the “widow’s dower.” Work on the hospital began immediately following the groundbreaking ceremony on March 8, 1948, the feast of St. John of God (who in 1540 established a house to harbor poor and sick persons). Four-and-a-half year old Brenda Kay Earle was the hospital’s first patient on May 15, 1952. Also in that year, Randall John Stewart was the first baby born there. In 2006, there were 4,900 employees and a 700-member medical staff. The hospital’s Emergency Room treated 8,287 patients during 1956, its first year.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Fr. [[Solanus Casey]], the first United States-born man to be declared "[[venerable]]" by the [[Roman Catholic Church]], died on July 31, 1957, in St. John Hospital (in Room 305 of the old wing, which has a plaque outside the door) at the age of 86.<ref>Jack Wintz, "Father Solanus Casey: Will He Be Beatified Soon? (Part I)," ''AmericanCatholic.org'', February 28, 2007.</ref>
In the 1960s Providence Hospital moved to [[Southfield, Michigan|Southfield]].<ref name=Greenehospitals/>
The Men’s Guild began in 1948 and is believed to have been the first men’s hospital fund raising group in the United States. It has 750 members that support its philanthropic efforts, highlighted by the Annual Guild Dinner.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}}
==Hospitals== St. John Providence is a member of the Roman Catholic [[Ascension Health]] Care System and operates the following hospitals:
* St. John Hospital & Medical Center ([[Detroit]]) [http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/StJohnHospital] * St. John Macomb-Oakland Hospital, Warren Campus ([[Warren, Michigan|Warren]]) [http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/Macomb] * St. John Macomb-Oakland Hospital, Madison Heights Campus ([[Madison Heights, Michigan|Madison Heights]]) [http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/Oakland] * Providence-Providence Park Hospital, Southfield * [[St. John Providence Park Hospital|Providence-Providence Park Hospital]], Novi * St. John River District Hospital ([[East China Township, Michigan|East China Township]]) [http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/RiverDistrict] * Brighton Center for Recovery ([[Brighton Township, Michigan|Brighton Township]]) [http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/Brighton]
It previously operated the St. John NorthEast Community Hospital in Detroit. It had 295 beds.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20030115033511/http://www.stjohn.org/hospitalscenters/ Hospitals & Centers]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/6HsWAnDaC?url=http://web.archive.org/web/20030115033511/http://www.stjohn.org/hospitalscenters/ Archive], ) St. John Health System. January 15, 2003. Retrieved on July 5, 2013.</ref> By 2003 the health system stated that it will remake the hospital into an outpatient center. In 2003 The Holy Cross Foundation made an initial offer to buy the hospital. The St. John System rejected the initial offer and stated that it still planned to remake the hospital, but the Holy Cross Foundation planned to make another offer.<ref>"Group pushes to buy St. John hospital." ''[[The Detroit News]]''. August 26, 2003. Retrieved on July 5, 2013. "A nonprofit group is still trying to buy St. John NorthEast Hospital, even though St. John Health System rejected the group's initial offer and says it will not deviate from plans to turn the hospital into an outpatient center. The Holy Cross Foundation -- a group of about 100 doctors and local activists created solely for keeping inpatient services open at the hospital -- plans to make another offer Wednesday. It has secured funding through the[...]" - Available in [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_action=keyword&s_search_type=keyword&p_product=DTNB&p_theme=gannett&s_site=detnews the archives] of ''The Detroit News'' under the ID det17082301.</ref>
In 2007 the [[St. John Riverview Hospital]] in Detroit closed.<ref name=StJohnssellstwo>"[http://detnews.com/article/20110201/BIZ/102010331/St.-John-sells-two-Detroit-facilities St. John sells two Detroit facilities]."{{dead link|date=July 2013}} ''[[The Detroit News]]''. February 1, 2011. Retrieved on July 4, 2013. "The Detroit News St. John Providence Health System said Monday that it has sold the former Riverview Hospital and its St. John Senior Community on East Warren in Detroit to an investment group. DRSN, led by Franklin attorney Richard Levin, plans to turn the Jefferson Avenue hospital, which closed in 2007, into a skilled nursing community. Renovations will begin immediately, and completion is expected this spring, according to a news release. A sales price is not being[...]" - Available in [http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_action=keyword&s_search_type=keyword&p_product=DTNB&p_theme=gannett&s_site=detnews the archives] of ''The Detroit News'' under the ID det-96806319. Also under the title "[http://detnews.com/article/20110131/BIZ/101310408/St.-John-Health-sells-Riverview-hospital St. John Health sells Riverview hospital]."{{dead link|date=July 2013}} on January 31, 2011.</ref> In 2011 the system sold the St. John Senior Community Center and the closed Riverview Hospital, both in Detroit, to DRSN, an investment group.<ref name=StJohnssellstwo/>
==Child health care== St. John Hospital’s Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) opened in 1970. St. John is also a regional referral center for high-risk pregnancies. In 1952 there were 855 births took place in the first delivery rooms back versus 3,893 in 2001 at the St. John Birthing Center. The facility is able to serve 31 mothers, infants and families for labor, delivery, recovery and postpartum care.
==Surgery== St. John offers diagnostic, surgical and non-surgical cardiac treatment. The first laparoscopic gallbladder removal procedure in Michigan was performed in 1989 at St. John. The Transplant Specialty Center opened in 1990 and in 1992 the first pancreas transplant took place. In 1993, the first kidney removal using a laparoscope was performed. Before the end of 2000, the Transplant Specialty Center had performed its 500th organ transplant.
==Cancer care==
The St. John Hospital and Medical Center Oncology Department began in 1968 and is now located in the recently opened Van Elslander Cancer Center (VECC) on the hospital's campus. The {{convert|69000|sqft|m2|sing=on}}facility focuses on offering holistic treatment and conventional cancer therapies.
Affiliated with the University of Michigan Cancer Center Network, the VanElslander Cancer Center, along with the University of Michigan and other St. John Health System hospitals treats more than 14,000 new cancer cases every year.
==Medical education== St. John Providence teaching hospitals educate new physicians in [[family medicine]], [[general surgery]], [[internal medicine]], [[OB/GYN]], radiology, pathology, [[pediatrics]], [[podiatric surgery]] and [[emergency medicine]] for physicians' post-medical school training, plus residency in Pharmacy Practices for post-degree students. In addition, St. John serves as a practical training site for students of Nursing, Pharmacy, Medical Laboratory Science, and Physical and Occupational Therapy, among others.
==References== {{reflist|33em}}
==Further reading== *Greene, Jay. "[http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20111023/SUB01/310239982/physicians-st-john-providence-form-aco-gain-contracting-power Physicians, St. John Providence form ACO, gain contracting power]." ''[[Crain's Detroit Business]]''. October 23, 2013.
==External links== {{Portal|Metro Detroit|Health}} * [http://www.stjohnprovidence.org/default.aspx St. John Providence Health System] * [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.stjohn.org/ St. John Health System Detroit Hospitals] (Archive)
{{Ascension Health}} {{Detroit}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Saint John Providence Health System}} [[Category:Hospital buildings completed in 1952]] [[Category:Economy of Detroit]] [[Category:Hospitals affiliated with the Catholic Church]] [[Category:Hospitals in Michigan]]

'''Willy Angerer''' (c. 1905 – July 21, 1936) was an Austrian mountaineer. He was one of four mountaineers who died in the [[1936 Eiger north face climbing disaster]], along with [[Toni Kurz]], [[Andreas Hinterstoisser]] and [[Eduard Rainer]].<ref>{{citation |title=Grindelwald: The Eiger |pages=1, 3 |publisher=Jungfrau Region Marketing AG |date= |url=http://jungfrauregion.ch/cmsfiles/the_eiger_jungfrau_region_e.pdf |accessdate=2016-12-28 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150523110749/http://jungfrauregion.ch/cmsfiles/the_eiger_jungfrau_region_e.pdf |archivedate=2016-12-28 }}</ref> At twenty-seven Angerer was the oldest of the four climbers who died.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Willis |first=Clint |title=The Boys of Everest: The Tragic Story of Climbing's Greatest Generation |publisher=Pavilion Books |year=8 December 2014 |location=New York |page=62 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h1DACAAAQBAJ&pg=PT62 |isbn=978-1-91023-219-4 }}</ref>
==Background== In the 1930s the mile-high [[North face (Eiger)|north-face of the Eiger]], that in the 1930s was considered to be the ''last great Alpine problem''.<ref name="mountain names">{{cite book |last=Julyan |first=Robert Hixson |title=Mountain Names |publisher=[[The Mountaineers (club)|The Mountaineers]] |date=1984 |location=Seattle |page=84 |isbn=0-89886-054-7 }}</ref> In the summer of 1935 two Bavarian climbers died attempting the climb despite a rescue attempt. Four climbers, two [[Austrian people|Austrians]] and two [[German people|Germans]], arrived in [[Alpiglen]], a settlement of [[Grindelwald]], in July 1936, intending to climb independently.<ref name="extreme eiger"/>
==The climb== [[File:Eiger Nordwand - panoramio (1).jpg|thumb|North face of the Eiger where Angerer and his colleagues died]] The two Austrians, Angerer and Rainer, reconnoitered the route for a good line on July 6 because the previous attempt by [[Karl Mehringer]] and [[Max Sedlmeyer]] had taken two days to climb the first 700 meters and their conditions were not good, so retreated. On 18 July Angerer and Rainer returned to the mountain to restart their attempt.<ref name="extreme eiger"/> A rock fall injured Angerer in the head on 20 July 1936, forcing them to descend. However, when they reached the very difficult ''Hinterstoisser traverse'', now ice covered due to the worsening weather conditions, from which the rope had been removed on the way up, they were unable to retreat through to safety and were forced to descend straight down. They were hit by an avalanche which carried Hinterstoisser away, while Angerer was violently crushed against the wall and strangled to death by the rope around his neck. Rainer, being pressed against the rock wall with the rope tight around his waist, froze to death. The only survivor, Toni Kurz, died the next day, within a few meters above his rescuers, but inaccessible.<ref name="extreme eiger">{{cite book |last=Gillman |first=Peter |author2=Gillman, Leni |title=Extreme Eiger: The Race to Climb the Direct Route up the North Face of the Eiger |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]] |date=4 June 2015 |location=London |pages=35–36 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sa2dBAAAQBAJ&pg=PP35 |isbn=978-1-47113-460-9 }}</ref>
Kurz was the last to die, hanging in his harness a few meters from a tunnel opening where a rescue team tried in vain to help him. With the mounting deaths on the Eiger's north face, the German press name "Nordwand" (North wall) was soon punned in sensational reports as "Mordwand" that translates in English as "murder wall".<ref name="mountain names"/>
==Legacy== Angerer and his fellow alpinists' tragedy became well known after the publication of [[Heinrich Harrer]]'s classic 1960 book ''[[The White Spider]].''<ref name="uk-climbing"/> The [[Edward Whymper]] disaster, during which four alpinists died, on the [[first ascent of the Matterhorn]] seventy-one years before, had formerly been the most publicised Alpine disaster.<ref name="extreme eiger"/> The 1936 event was covered by [[Joe Simpson (mountaineer)|Joe Simpson]]'s 2007 book (and [[International Emmy Awards|Emmy]]-winning TV documentary), ''[[The Beckoning Silence]]'', as well as in the 2008 German dramatic movie ''[[North Face (film)|North Face]]''.<ref name="uk-climbing">{{cite web|last=Cooper |first=Kate |title=The Eiger Nordwand Revealed: Rainer Rettner Interview |publisher=UK Climbing |date=May 2008 |url=http://www.ukclimbing.com/articles/page.php?id=1004 |accessdate=2016-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{imdb title|id=0844457|title=North Face}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073735/http://walking.about.com/od/traileurope/ig/Eiger-Trail-Photos/Rote-Fluh-and-Hinterstoisser.htm Rote Fluh and Hinterstoisser Traverse] Eiger north face photos - [[Wayback Machine]] archive

revision.comment: remove copyright content copied from https://web.archive.org/web/20120528170649/http://www.wgnrr.org/current-campaigns . remove inappropriate inline external links
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=June 2012}}
{{Infobox non-profit | name = Women's Global Network for Reproductive Rights (WGNRR) | image = Logo_for_Women's_Global_Network_for_Reproductive_Rights.png | type = Non-Governmental Organization | founded_date = 1984 | location = Manila, Philippines | focus = Sexual and reproductive health and rights | homepage = www.wgnrr.org }}
'''Women's Global Network for Reproductive Rights''' (WGNRR) is an international [[non-governmental organization]] (NGO) that advocates for sexual and [[reproductive health]] and rights worldwide. Based in the Global South, they are a membership-driven organization that "works within the rights, justice and [[feminist]] frameworks."<ref>{{cite web|title=WGNRR: Vision, Mission and Values|url=http://www.wgnrr.org/who-we-are|publisher=WGNRR|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref> WGNRR works towards the realization of the full sexual and reproductive health and rights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.defendingwomen-defendingrights.org/about/members/womens-global-network-for-reproductive-rights/|title=Women’s Global Network for Reproductive Rights {{!}}|website=www.defendingwomen-defendingrights.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref> WGNRR has consultative status with [[ECOSOC]].<ref>{{cite web|title=NGO Branch: UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs|url=http://esango.un.org/civilsociety/showProfileDetail.do?method=showProfileDetails&profileCode=603827|publisher=ECOSOC|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref>
== History ==
WGNRR was founded at the fourth International Women and Health Meeting in 1984.<ref name="cccg.umontreal">{{cite journal|last=Estrada-Claudio|first=Sylvia|title=THE INTERNATIONAL WOMEN AND HEALTH MEETINGS: CATALYST AND END PRODUCT OF THE GLOBAL FEMINIST HEALTH MOVEMENT|date=April 26, 2006|url=http://www.cccg.umontreal.ca/pdf/Sylvia%20Estrada-Claudio_en.pdf}}</ref> The conference was themed "No to Population Control... Women Decide!" and saw the formation of other important international networks including Women Living Under Muslim Laws (WLUML) and Latin American Women and Health Network.<ref name="cccg.umontreal" /> In 1987, at another IWHM conference, WGNRR partnered with the Latin America and Caribbean Women’s Health Network to launch a campaign addressing maternal mortality and declared May 28 the International Day of Action for Women's Health.<ref>{{cite web|last=Portugal|first=Ana Maria|title=Highlights of the Latin American and Caribbean Women's Health Movement|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0MDX/is_2-3_2004/ai_n27847398/|accessdate=June 12, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Using human rights to improve maternal and neonatal health: history, connections and a proposed practical approach|url=http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/86/8/07-050500/en/index.html|publisher=World Health Organization|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref> WGNRR was an active participant in the International Conference “Reinforcing Reproductive Rights”, held in Madras, India in 1993. It was this year that WGNRR began campaigning for safe and legal [[abortion]].<ref name="wgnrr">{{cite web|title=WGNRR: History|url=http://www.wgnrr.org/history|accessdate=June 12, 2012}}</ref> WGNRR's position on abortion was critical during the [[International Conference on Population and Development]] (ICPD) in 1994. According to their website, "WGNRR was part of a coalition – the Women’s Alliance – to ensure that women’s voices were heard and represented at the conference. that protested the population control theories that abounded at the time. WGNRR was also involved in workshops protesting the use of anti-fertility “vaccines”. WGNRR’s support of the ICPD’s inclusion of right to access of safe abortion was still tempered by its concern over the language and the fear of the misuse of such a document by proponents of coerced population control."<ref name="wgnrr" /> In 1995, WGNRR undertook campaigns to address the [[feminisation of poverty]] and was an active participant in the development of the [[Programme of Action]] for the Women’s World Conference in Beijing.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/pad.305 | volume=24 | title=Interpreting reproductive rights: institutional responses to the agenda in the 1990s | journal=Public Administration and Development | pages=41–50 | last1 = Xiaoquan Zhang | first1 = Heather}}</ref> Following the Cairo Consensus, WGNRR held a 1996 Regional Members' Meeting in Amsterdam. Between 2003 to 2007, WGNRR collaborated with the People’s Health Movement on the Women’s Access to Health campaign.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women's Access to Health Campaign|url=http://www.phmovement.org/en/campaigns/33/page|publisher=People's Health Movement|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref> WGNRR then relocated its main office to the Global South and by 2009, the main office was transferred from the [[Netherlands]] to the [[Philippines]].<ref name="wgnrr" />
== Key areas == * Access to safe and legal abortion * Access to [[contraceptives]] * [[Abortion-rights movements|abortion rights]] advocacy * Youth sexual and reproductive health rights * Women's sexual and reproductive health rights * Sexual rights for all people
== Campaigns == WGNRR has facilitated several international campaigns on a wide range of issues including [[maternal mortality]] and morbidity, poverty, [[forced sterilization]] and the sexual and [[reproductive rights]] of youth. Since its inception, WGNRR has used "Calls for Action" to mobilize members.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Humble|first=Morag|title=Window on the World: Reproductive Rights and Health Movements|journal=Development|year=2005|volume=48|issue=4|doi=10.1057/palgrave.development.1100196|url=http://www.palgrave-journals.com/development/journal/v48/n4/full/1100196a.html|accessdate=June 13, 2012|pages=144}}</ref> WGNRR's two primary campaigns are the International Day of Action for Women's Health (May 28) and the International Day of Action for Access to Safe and Legal Abortion (September 28).
=== Global Day of Action for Access to Safe and Legal Abortion === September 28 was chosen as the date for the Latin American and Caribbean Campaign for the Decriminalization of Abortion in 1990.<ref name="wgnrr_a">{{cite web|url=http://www.wgnrr.org/current-campaigns|title=WGNRR: Current Campaigns|accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref> In 2015, the name of the day was changed to [[International Safe Abortion Day]] in an attempt to have a simpler, easier to remember name and to advocate for the day to become an official UN day.<ref>http://www.safeabortionwomensright.org/international-safe-abortion-day/</ref>
== Funders == WGNRR works in partnership with and has received recent funding from [[Oxfam Novib]] and The Safe Abortion Action Fund (SAAF).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wgnrr.org/funders/|title=Funders {{!}} WGNRR|website=wgnrr.org|language=en|access-date=2018-05-20}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Reproductive rights]] [[Category:Women's rights organizations]]
